Counter-Strike 2 - A Disappointing Departure from the Franchise's Legacy Introduction: Counter-Strike 2, the latest iteration in the iconic franchise developed by Valve Corporation, fails to live up to the lofty standards set by its predecessors. Despite the anticipation surrounding the sequel, Counter-Strike 2 falls short in multiple aspects, leaving longtime fans and newcomers alike with a sense of dissatisfaction. Underwhelming Visual Upgrades: One of the most disappointing aspects of Counter-Strike 2 is its lackluster visual upgrades. In an era where graphical advancements are expected, the game's visuals feel dated and fail to capitalize on the potential for immersive environments. Character models lack detail, and the overall aesthetic lacks the modern polish seen in contemporary shooters, resulting in a lack of visual impact. Stagnant Gameplay Mechanics: Counter-Strike has always been known for its precise and tactical gameplay, but Counter-Strike 2 does little to innovate or evolve the mechanics that made the franchise a success. The gameplay feels stagnant, offering little in the way of fresh features or improvements. With other shooters pushing the boundaries of the genre, Counter-Strike 2 feels like a missed opportunity to breathe new life into the series. Lack of Innovation in Maps: Counter-Strike has a rich history of iconic maps, but Counter-Strike 2 disappoints with its uninspired map design. The lack of innovation in both visual style and layout results in a sense of déjà vu, with maps that feel all too familiar. The absence of new, memorable locations diminishes the excitement of exploration and strategy that the Counter-Strike series is known for. Microtransaction Overemphasis: Counter-Strike 2 leans heavily into microtransactions, introducing a plethora of cosmetic items and skins that often feel disconnected from the game's military aesthetic. The emphasis on monetization detracts from the core experience, creating a sense that the game prioritizes profit over player satisfaction. The overabundance of microtransactions undermines the purity of the Counter-Strike experience. Inadequate Anti-Cheat Measures: The prevalence of cheaters has long been a concern in the Counter-Strike community, and Counter-Strike 2 does little to address this issue. The inadequate anti-cheat measures result in frustrating gameplay experiences, with legitimate players often encountering unfair advantages from those exploiting the system. This lack of effective countermeasures tarnishes the competitive integrity of the game. Poor Communication and Community Engagement: Counter-Strike has thrived on its dedicated community, but Counter-Strike 2 struggles with poor communication and community engagement from the developers. The lack of transparency regarding updates, bug fixes, and the future direction of the game leaves players feeling disconnected and uninformed. This lack of engagement fosters an environment of uncertainty and frustration within the player base. Technical Issues and Unpolished Release: Counter-Strike 2 suffers from a myriad of technical issues and a general lack of polish that is uncharacteristic of a major release. From connectivity problems to in-game glitches, the overall stability of the game is compromised. The decision to release the game in such a state undermines the reputation of the Counter-Strike franchise for delivering high-quality, polished experiences. Conclusion: Counter-Strike 2 disappoints on multiple fronts, failing to evolve the franchise in a meaningful way and neglecting the elements that made its predecessors legendary. With underwhelming visuals, stagnant gameplay, an overemphasis on microtransactions, and inadequate anti-cheat measures, Counter-Strike 2 falls short of the expectations set by its iconic predecessors. The lack of innovation, poor community engagement, and technical issues make Counter-Strike 2 a regrettable entry in a series that once set the standard for excellence in the first-person shooter genre.

CSGO was great. The community servers were awesome and the main reason I played the game. However, the forced merger of CSGO with CS2 has rendered the state of the servers and communities nearly obsolete, replaced by an inferior, but prettier version of the game. What was fun, is now anti-fun. Part of this is due to the poor performance and higher demand required to play CS2, but also because the larger more complex custom maps can no longer be played. In addition, what took over 10 years to build a rich and highly detailed variety of custom maps has been wiped out with this update. It will probably be several years until we even reach parity with the quality of custom maps that CSGO had, if the community survives. If you are someone who was/is part of Zombie Escape community, thank you for playing throughout all these years. Also, thanks to the creators of the custom maps and their continued support, despite Valve. Playing this game mode (and others) was a blast.

Counter Strike 2 is a highly anticipated continuation of the famous shooter game series. While the game brings many improvements and interesting new features, I have to mention that I found the movement of the characters to be quite strange and not very natural. Sometimes, it feels like the characters move in an unusual manner and it doesn't feel as fluid as in other similar games. Additionally, I have noticed that there are moments when death occurs frustratingly from someone who is running and shooting in a peculiar way. This can be quite disappointing and can lead to a less enjoyable gaming experience. However, I remain optimistic that the developers will address these issues and resolve these aspects in future updates. Counter Strike 2 has tremendous potential, with impressive graphics and a passionate player community. If the developers work on adjusting the movement and improving gameplay aspects, I am confident that this game will reach the level of quality and popularity of its predecessor, Counter Strike Global Offensive.

As someone with twice as much time in the Map Editor for CSGO as the game itself CS2 is one of biggest letdowns I've ever experienced. I don't think I'll ever understand why they clung to the Summer 2023 deadline rather than just waiting for content parity with CSGO. The import tools from CSGO to CS2 is not easy to understand and the documentation is confusing, and even when a map is successfully ported to CS2 it is likely to be missing half the assets because some maps just do not exist in CS2. The fact that this replaced CSGO means either I deal with the porting tools or just allow my work to be lost to time. So far CS2 has been nothing but letdown after letdown, do not bother with this game if you're looking for a game that caters to Counter-Strike's history of community content.

Spent way too much money, time, and nerves on CSGO, but I still LOVED every second of it. This CS2 bullsh*t, on the other hand, is pure garbanzo. Just a money grab. I did understand that the game was buggy, broken, and unfinished in the Limited Beta release, but now it has been officially fully released for more than 2 weeks, as of writing this, and the game is still unplayable. Performance issues aside, the game is just broken. How did they manage to fu*k up 2 of the best weapons in the game? -AK-47: You can't spray at all anymore; it seems super random. Bullet tracers don't help but make it even worse. -AWP: Flicks feel so bad; it used to be super fun to hit those insane flick shots on CSGO. Now, you have to aim at someone and just then shoot, which is Valorant's "Operator" 1/1. Maybe guns are just a personal problem; okay, I can understand that. Sometimes it's hard for a player with over 6k hours to adapt to something new, so let's talk about some other stuff. "You get what you see." Not only did they lock the servers to 64-tick, but there is not even a way to change it anymore. Subtick feels super bad. Shots don't go where you expect them to go. You kill people more often if you shoot behind/in front of them than if you aim directly at them. CSGO used to have a player model problem, where the hitbox of a character was not the same as the player model, but that's nothing compared to this. Also, dying behind a wall is something that you have to get used to because it happens 9/10 times if somebody peeks you while you try to hide. Missing commands are also a huge problem. -(cl_righthand) Many good CSGO players change the hand in which you hold the weapon mid-rounds because they want to see 2 different positions without having to move and lose the angle. That is not possible anymore. -(cl_bob_lower_amt) Most people that I know and watch used this command to stop the weapon from moving while you walk/run. Here, you cannot do it anymore, which is a shame because it is super annoying. -(r_cleardecals) You cannot clear the blood anymore, which makes a huge difference. As a long-time fan of the Counter-Strike series, I was thrilled to dive into Counter-Strike 2, and I can confidently say that it has exceeded my expectations in every aspect. Gameplay: Counter-Strike 2 maintains the classic, intense gameplay that the series is known for while introducing innovative features that breathe new life into the experience. The addition of new weapons, tactical gadgets, and maps keeps the game feeling fresh and exciting. The balance between terrorists and counter-terrorists remains impeccable, ensuring that every match is a thrilling battle of wits. Graphics: The graphics in Counter-Strike 2 are a significant leap forward from its predecessor. The attention to detail in character models, weapon designs, and environmental elements is commendable. The updated visuals enhance the overall immersion, making every firefight feel more realistic and intense. Sound Design: The sound design in Counter-Strike 2 deserves special mention. From the distinct footsteps echoing through different environments to the satisfyingly realistic gun sounds, every audio element contributes to the immersive atmosphere of the game. It's not just eye candy; it's ear candy too. New Features: Counter-Strike 2 introduces several new features that add depth to the gameplay. The ability to customize weapons and equipment loadouts adds a layer of strategy, allowing players to tailor their approach to different maps and scenarios. The inclusion of a robust ranking system and seasonal events keeps the community engaged and motivated. Community and Support: The developers have shown a commendable commitment to fostering a vibrant community around Counter-Strike 2. Regular updates, responsive support, and a clear dedication to addressing player feedback demonstrate that the team is invested in the long-term success of the game. Conclusion: Counter-Strike 2 is not just a sequel; it's a testament to the evolution of tactical gaming. It successfully builds upon the foundation laid by its predecessors, delivering an experience that caters to both veterans and newcomers. With its engaging gameplay, stunning visuals, and a thriving community, Counter-Strike 2 has firmly secured its place as a must-play title for any FPS enthusiast. Whether you're a fan of the series or a newcomer to the genre, Counter-Strike 2 is an absolute triumph.

So I have not the foggiest idea what Valve has done but this game is completely unplayable: 1. No settings were carried forward from CS:GO and as such I have: - lost my cross-hair settings, - lost my handedness (I am a lefty), - lost all my keybindings and related settings. 2. When attempting to set the game to full-screen mode with a 16:9 aspect ratio, there are no options for the correct resolution for my monitor/NVIDIA settings/Windows 10 settings; ie 1920 x 1080, the highest I am able to set it is 1600 x 900 which is beyond fuzzy and unclear. 3. When trying to change any video settings; ie brightness and advanced options, etc; the resolution automatically reverts back to 1600 x 900, even after after setting optimum settings in NVIDIA to force a resolution of 1920 x 1080. 4. After doing a full reinstall, there is now severe and brain glitching audio stuttering, hearing all sounds a minimum of 2 or 3 times. Upon further investigation, it appears that no matter how high-end the PC being used these audio issues, to date, remain unresolved. Resetting all settings to default also does absolutely nothing to resolve any of the above issues. I am absolutely disgusted by the unfulfilled big promises, such as forward compatibility (which only seems to apply to money-generating items, such as skins). Additionally, the vast majority of maps seem to be missing as well as the casual and fun game modes, such as Arms Race, etc. Furthermore, CS2 has completely overwritten and voided all the CS:GO achievements which many of us have spent countless hours working on. I was quite excited about this rework of a classic game, however, it has been completely butchered and we do not even have the option to play the original CS:GO. So congratulations Valve on another job well done, it is truly no wonder why the only lonely achievement for CS2 (which appears to be gained by simply playing a round, including “return to training day” against bots) has only been acquired by 13.1% of all players.

Gonna preface this by saying, I'm no professional. I get that this game needs polish and yes it released too early I agree, but that does not make this a bad game by any means. As of recent CS2 has felt heaps better than it did at release. The game is tons of fun to play especially with friends and with how the new engine reacts and looks is absolutely stunning. I would change some things of course, premiere ranking system (not sure what was wrong with the old ranks), per map ranks on comp, bringing back Overwatch or implement better anti-cheat, etc. but Valve is not just gonna let one of the biggest competitive shooters just die. These things will come in one form or another and this game will be everything people want it to be, will just need time. Overall, 8/10 loving the game and find myself playing it more than I did with CSGO.

I've been a Counter-Strike fan since the early days, and I was eagerly anticipating the release of Counter-Strike 2 (CS2). From the moment I booted up the game, I was blown away by the visuals. The Source 2 engine brings the game's environments and characters to life in stunning detail, and the overall graphical overhaul is truly impressive. The gameplay is also top-notch. CS2 retains the core mechanics that have made Counter-Strike a success for over two decades, but it also introduces new features that make the game feel fresh and modern. The team-based gameplay is as strategic and intense as ever, and the game's competitive depth is unmatched. However, my enjoyment of CS2 has been dampened by the prevalence of cheating. I've encountered a number of cheaters in my online matches, and it's starting to ruin the experience for me. It's frustrating to play against someone who is clearly using aimbots or other hacks, and it makes it difficult to enjoy the game's competitive nature. I know that Valve is working on improving VAC, but it doesn't seem to be enough at the moment. Cheating is a serious problem in CS2, and it's something that Valve needs to address as soon as possible. Overall, Counter-Strike 2 is a visually stunning and mechanically refined first-person shooter that would be a lot more enjoyable if it weren't for the prevalence of cheating.

ALL they had to do was fix the smokes and update the graphics, maybe play around with gun balance. Instead we get an absolute mess, peekers advantage so insane you don't even see people on your screen before you die, added randomness to sprays to remove a previous core skill of the game, moving accuracy buffed so you end up getting head-shot by people full running with AKs on a regular basis, hit reg worse than csgo, just an absolute disaster of a sequel. Add onto that the fact the cheating problem was not addressed in the slightest and the new matchmaking system is just as broken as the last one. These were the two main complaints from the community and they didn't even try. It's obvious the passion of valve is long gone by now, I guess all that steam money and case money removes any incentive to actually try. P.S Using all of the old reviews from csgo as if cs2 is just an update is dishonest business practice, and the fact that enough people have gone to the effort of going back and editing their review to drop the score this much shows just how bad this game is.

Dota 2, the iconic multiplayer online battle arena (MOBA) game developed by Valve, stands as a testament to the depth and complexity that the genre can offer. With its steep learning curve, diverse hero roster, and strategic intricacies, Dota 2 has cemented its place as one of the most challenging and rewarding competitive games in the world. From the outset, Dota 2 impresses with its stunning visuals and attention to detail. The diverse and intricately designed heroes, each with a unique set of abilities, contribute to the game's rich tapestry. The maps are expansive, and the visual effects during intense clashes are nothing short of spectacular, creating an immersive experience for players. The heart of Dota 2 lies in its strategic depth. Matches are not won by individual skill alone but require teamwork, coordination, and a deep understanding of hero synergies and counterplays. The game's draft phase, where teams select their heroes, sets the stage for intricate mind games and strategic planning, adding a layer of anticipation to each match. The dynamic metagame ensures that no two matches are alike, as players adapt to patches and balance changes, keeping the gameplay fresh and exciting. The constant evolution of strategies, combined with regular updates and new hero releases, contributes to the game's longevity and the enthusiasm of its dedicated player base. Dota 2's esports scene is legendary, with annual tournaments like The International boasting record-breaking prize pools. The level of competition and the sheer skill displayed by professional players add to the game's allure, making it a spectator sport that captivates fans worldwide. However, Dota 2 is not without its challenges. The learning curve can be daunting for newcomers, and the community, while passionate, can be unforgiving to those still mastering the game. Additionally, the length of matches can be a double-edged sword, offering epic battles but also demanding a significant time commitment. In conclusion, Dota 2 is a masterpiece of the MOBA genre, offering an unparalleled blend of strategic depth, skill expression, and a vibrant competitive scene. While it may not be the most accessible game for newcomers, those who invest the time to master its complexities will find a rewarding and enduring gaming experience that continues to evolve with each passing season.

Playing Dota 2 on SEA server is like stepping into a battlefield of passion, chaos, and unpredictable outcomes. It's not for the faint of heart, but if you can survive the storm, you'll come out the other side with stories to tell and a newfound appreciation for the diverse world of Dota 2.

Dota 2 is among the most complex games. MOBAs only end when a base collapses, in contrast to other games like first-person shooters and fighting games, which are always played with a time restriction. Compared to League of Legends, Dota 2 has a larger area with less teleportation, meaning that resource and economic management is a laborious process in the game. You purchase the greatest things with the cash and experience you gain from taking out enemy heroes, camps, and creeps. Things start to radically shift for both teams towards the end of the game. Ascension is a major theme in Dota 2, which offers players countless strategies for defeating their rivals. For essential items, teams can purchase Black King Bar, Lotus Orb, and Linken’s Sphere to deter any incoming debuff. There’s also a long list of tier 5 neutral items that players can pick up from creep camps after the 60-minute mark. Heroes also get stronger and stronger with talent trees that provide amplified stats on either skills or attributes. Players also have the ability to prolong engagements with the Buyback option, which truly matters in the late game where death timers reach minutes. Looking at the map, you have bounties, runes, and outposts to capture as well as Roshan who provides the Aegis of the Immortal — an item that resurrects a fallen hero to full health and mana — and some cheese. Needless to say, Dota 2 doesn’t shy away from giving limitless opportunities to players and teams. With no real time limit to the game, you’ll experience thrilling wombo combos and defiant item builds in every match that you play. Going seven years strong as a casual Dota 2 player, I’m still dumbfounded at a lot of things that I see. It might even take another seven years for me to nail everything down to a tee.

> find an interesting video about the champion Io > enjoy support/healing, want to give it a try > install Dota 2, hop into a coop vs AI match to try it > queue takes several minutes > finally pops, end up with all bots on my team and enemy team, no other players but me > wait, I can't select Io. why not? > leave > get penalized for leaving a bot match filled with bots, great > find on google that I can enable the console and type dota_new_player 0 to skip some built-in anti-noob function that forces a bunch of complex heroes to be unselectable for new players under 25 games, even during a match vs AI bots, including Io > set it up, try it, requeue > wait another ~5 minutes for the queue to pop > still can't select Io. In a bot match. Against bots. Not ranked. Just bots. > leave, penalized again, great > newer google results say it's actually dota_new_player false, not 0 > try again.. long queue.. 1 other player.. all the rest bots > still can't select Io > try the 'new player queue' or w/e its called > Io not even an option, just a handful of the easiest champs > uninstall > try LoL > surprisingly easy to get into - item buying interface is much simpler to understand > no mule to bring you items but it's easy to press B to teleport back home and grab what you need > actually has short videos showcasing each ability so you can see how it works instead of just reading it and guessing like in Dota 2 > coop vs AI queue is instant > it's actually 5 humans vs 5 AI bots > no heroes are grayed out and unselectable > fun was had screw Dota 2

Game sucks, I hate it with a passion but cannot stop playing it for some reason. you know if you win or lose in the first 10 mins of a match, but you need to stick out the remainder of the 45mins anyways. Match win is almost fully dependent on who picks the most OP hero, and gets the best start. Out of almost 500 matches, I've had maybe 5 comeback wins. The learning curve is big, but its mainly just learning the hero skills and what items to buy (also you'll be buying the same thing every match, there is little to no variation in the matches) Valve also claims to change the meta with patching heros, but this generally just results in minuscule changes, and even buffs to already OP heros. Don't even get me started on the god awful matchmaking...

Dota 2 offers a high level of complexity and strategic depth. The vast number of heroes, each with unique abilities, allows for diverse playstyles and strategic approaches. The dynamic nature of the game, with ever-evolving team compositions and in-game events, keeps matches engaging and challenging.

Dota 1 veteran here. The reason Dota 2 do not gain new players is because they're scared of being matched with people with 10,000 hours who thinks they know the game. I've matched against people with 10,000 hours of playtime, I completely obliterated them in a rank game. Nobody knows everything in DOTA, we're all here figuring it out. Every game is unique. It is normal to lose some games. This Game 's skill Ceiling is very high. Very Enjoyable if you know what you are doing. The Internet says the game is dying, this is not true. Always being patched regularly, you will get mad because of huge updates and your main being nerfed. Communication is a must, don't pick up the game if you don't play as a team. Carrying your team is the goal.

Dota 2 is an absolute masterpiece in the world of online gaming, seamlessly blending breathtaking graphics, strategic depth, and an expansive hero roster. The game's immersive gameplay and dynamic team-based battles make every match an exhilarating experience. The attention to detail in character design, coupled with the constantly evolving map, showcases the developers' commitment to delivering a visually stunning and engaging environment. The robust community and regular updates from the developers ensure that Dota 2 remains at the forefront of the MOBA genre. The competitive scene is vibrant, providing players with the opportunity to witness and participate in high-stakes tournaments. The free-to-play model is player-friendly, allowing anyone to dive into the action without financial barriers. Overall, Dota 2 stands as a testament to the heights that multiplayer gaming can achieve, making it a must-play for both casual and competitive gamers alike.

No doubt the best MOBA, although it's hard not to suck at it unless you put tons of time into it. But even if you DO suck, it's still a good time with friends, and the pro scene is really fun to follow, if esports is your thing (the latter is a big chunk of my hours in this game).

I, like many other players, am very disappointed in PUBG. This game was promised as the future of online gaming, but in reality it is a complete failure. It constantly slows down and lags, which makes the gameplay not only slow but also terribly annoying. In addition, the game's graphics look outdated and are not up to modern standards. Also, I don't like the way PUBG developers treat their players. They don't listen to feedback and don't improve the game according to user requests. Instead, they release new updates with bugs and errors that only make the gameplay worse. Overall, PUBG is a game that I wouldn't recommend to anyone. Not only is it not enjoyable, but it is a complete waste of time and money. If you want to play a good online game, you better choose something else.

Bought when released. Often go back and have a good few hours of fun. Learning curve is relatively steep, but still accessible to part time players. Movement is a little awkward and unique still, but the gunplay in my opinion is very enjoyable. In addition to the opportunity for quick fast games, it's a good one to have in the library. FPP is a must.

I am a long follower and player of pubg since watching Node and their zombie series. I waited and waited for it to come to console, then finally got a PC of my own. I cannot recommend PUBG anymore, it is aged and is outpaced in terms of battle royale enjoyment for me. It is slow paced, you will go 15 minutes of looting and not seeing anybody then one engagement that you have no idea where you got shot from and your back in the lobby. This isn't just me crying because I'm bad too. The amount of people playing this game that are actually from NA amounts to that less than a population of a farmstead in the middle of nebraska. You will not enjoy your time with this game once you are past your bot lobbies. Recoil will take ages to learn. Audio is so loud you can tell the room and building some dude is in from the other side of the city. You might have some good games, but overall the skill gap and sweats will stop you from enjoying over 10 hours these days.

Very clunky, glitches, bugs, FPS drops, desync, you name it! Still, I can live with all of the above... One thing I cannot stand though is the massive cheating/hacking which ruins the experience for everyone. You can drop in Pochinki, Pecado, Boot Camp, Podvosto or Hayek and wipe the entire city, only to have a hacker kill you with a suppressed 4x Beryl spray from 200m mid-game and ruin it for the entire team. People cheat blatantly and the developers do little to stop them. And when they do ban them, it is a "temporary ban". What do you mean "temporary"? If you cheat, you should get banned permanently. End of story. The only thing they are good at is selling silly content (weapon skins, costumes, season passes, etc...) instead of focusing on the more pressing matters. I have no faith in what the developers say or promise anymore. Utterly disappointed.

In simple terms this game can be summarized into two words "TRASH GAME". On a detailed note, here is what I found out after my frustrated gameplay sessions spanning over few months. 1. One of the worst optimized game that I have ever played in my experience. The game literally hiccups when you have an airplane flying over you. I noticed this across different system specs. I had a ryzen 5 3550 H with GTX 1650 with 4Gb Vram, on all low settings and my fps drops from 60 to like 25. My friend has the exact same issue, where he has an i9 13900k with RTX 3060 12 Gb Vram running on all low settings, his fps also drops like from 100 to 50-60 fps. Well in this case there is no point blaming my system specs as the issue. I don't need more than 60fps to have good gameplay experience. But the devs are no longer bothered in polishing the game to make it better. I know it requires a complete redo from scratch, but the sheer incompetence from PUBG devs simply makes this game a joke. 2. The same issue occurs when there are so many players concentrated in one region like making a hot drop or in the final zones. Just when the game needs to work smooth, you get the worst fps. Simply making the gaming experience unfair. With such a low TTK in the game the fps drops makes this game unplayable. And sometimes you don't even need much players to have the fps drop, just one or two enemies close to you is more than enough. 3. Every single game has players using recoil scripts. There is like almost 50% people running recoil scripts and it is pretty evident from watching the crosshair motion in spectate and replay mode. 4. Then you have players using macros to fire DMRs as if its is mk14 on full auto. 5. Then you have the wall hack people trying to sniping you across hard building walls with their wall hacks. 6. Then you have aimbots, but are somewhat less nowadays i guess. 7. Then there is the issue of bad hit register, where you fire at an enemy hit your shots, see the blood getting spilled but you literally did zero damage because he somehow killed me first? The biggest BS I have seen and dealing in this game. For people who says its my ping, I guess 54ms is not a bad ping to have such issues. 8. Being a free game has its pros but even more is the con especially when PUBG doesn't ban the hardware upon finding players are cheating. PUBG says or atleast we hope, bans players upon finding they are cheating, then they make new account (free game right?) and people with literally underwear and less than lv10 headshots you with beryl miles across the second you peek a wall with all the recoil scripts and aimbots. Again another big joke i.e. the pie charts PUBG posts every week regarding the players they ban and trying to show the community that they are making the gameplay experience better. 9. Most games, as of the date of posting ,are filled with bots. In a 100 player game, there will be around 40 real players and 60 bots. And new players are so happy getting kills on the bot as if they have carried the game. There are literally people who shoot at a bot just to get that easy kill even when there are actual players trying to get him. 10. I have to emphasise the fact that having an in game chat with teammates is a feature that will help when playing with randoms. Especially when the majority of the population playing this game are reluctant to speak the common language english or don't know to speak english at all. Out of like 10 games 9 games will have people who literally can't utter a word in english. But PUBG says they are matching me with people who speaks english and they even have a team finder option to match with people who speak the same language. Biggest BS of a feature PUBG has provided in the game. My native language is not even english but dude, if you can't speak or understand english, what is the point of even giving comms in random matches especially when you get matched mostly with people who can't speak or understand english. Hopefully there is a higher chance they can read english. But meh. 11. PUBG should allow people to select servers manually, that way atleast people can get into nearby servers where people can atleast communicate in same language and have some fun in random matches. 12. PUBGs movements are so janky. Sometimes you have to tap multiple times to get into ADS mode right after you exit out of a vehicle. I have died so many times in a 1v1 encounter, where the game literally hesitates to get me into ADS mode right after I exit vehicle. 13. You can't aim below horizontal level while you are shooting from a vehicle? I mean like what sort of a game mechanics is that? Its not even comparable in real life. I have died to enemies countless times, especially in scenarios where two vehicles crash and simply just because my vehicle was slightly at a greater elevation, and not being able to aim below horizontal level, I die. 14. Last but not the least, WTF is WELLBIA SECURITY SERVICE?Is it some chinese/korean malware,spyware or cryptominer?Every single time I start PUBG it keeps asking me to install wellbia security service 3 times. There is already an EAC running with the game and why is there even a need for some fishy additional software? And it literally makes no difference. I tried this. First I installed wellbia and found it running with pubg and even after i closed the game, assuming that wellbia was their EAC. Then i uninstalled the entire game and declined the permission to install wellbia. The game still works the same except now i don't have a chinese/korean fishy software running in the background always. If the game works without wellbia, why even ask players to install some fishy software. I mean already people don't trust them, and top of that literally exposing themselves of being the same fishy people. Nice job PUBG. I am ending this list here. There are literally so many more issues in the game and I don't want to waste my time anymore writing a review. My 2 cents on the people reading this review is, please try to stay away from this game and let the game die slowly. That way a lot of legit players will be saved from countless issue starting with system security and mental health. Please help the community by letting the game die.

Product received for free After getting over 3000 hours combining my Steam and Origin playtime, reaching level 500 back when that mattered and grinding with my friends all the way to Diamond league, I can't help but feel heartbroken over my poor time's waste. The masterfully made seamless inventory system, the satisfying weapons, the iconic maps and amazing music are all ruined by, of all things... the Legends. Time and time again, skill and risk-taking behavior are pushed aside for rock/paper/scissors combat based on crutches on a timer. Accuracy, positioning and movement can all be overridden with a push of a button just because someone picked a Legend to counter yours. Annoying scans, gas, get-out-of-jail-free-cards, pods that lock you to the ceiling to keep you from finishing off an enemy off guard. Apex isn't great because of the Legends, but despite of them. We don't need them. I gave up hope and haven't touched it since 2021. And until a bare-bones mode is added so I can play without them, I don't have the heart to touch it again. I miss you Havoc, my beloved...

Not to brag but after 200 hrs, I'm still bad at apex. In Conclusion, If you are considering getting in the mix in Apex, don't. You aren't meant for this game. The very fundamentals of the game are designed to hate new players. If you don't get how the guns work or how the abilities work you are destined to die in every encounter. Every once in a while the stars will align and you will get a heroin hit of a team wipe. However, just like heroin, it fades quickly when you die on the next encounter. This game is for the people who are still playing it since release. For those who have made a name for themselves and as such cant let the game go. Totally New Gameplay! The matchmaking system is the wackiest ive ever seen. Instead of taking your skill in combat into account, It's based on your survival. If you run and hide, you will get into the top 5 often and therefore be better. However, you will be thrown into harder and harder lobbies where you don't win fights. The guns are absurd. In the right hands, they will 2 shot you, in your hands they won't kill. No matter how many shots you put in. Snipers are an actual joke taking 3 to 5 shots to kill. The Ultimate's range from being handy to useless. Your character often has a strange glow that makes it very hard to stay hidden. Weapon xp is simply retarded. You get more xp by holding the gun then actually using it. The Legends are mostly annoying. Some will talk as if the Apex games are a tightrope of life and death and others talk as if it's just a backyard BBQ party. The maps are fine The community seemingly has a 30/70 split between helpful and hateful respectively. Either they complain about your lack of experience and demand that you leave. There is a shocking amount of randoms that will go off on their own and then die and in a shocking twist leave the game. Of which they will be penalized for. It's every 2 or 3 rounds.

I would've recommended this game around S13-S14, unfortunately that's not the case anymore. Here's a quickfire of all the things I think are negative in this game - Uninspired skins, lots of re-colours of already released skins - Bad matchmaking, Diamonds and Masters in Rookie lobbies - Bad community - Bad audio - Bad hit registration (the servers are running at 20 ticks, mind you today's standards are 64 tick or even 128 tick, you can find multiple clips of hit reg issues in Apex, just search on youtube) - Bad ranked system (for ~3 Seasons now) - Takes too long to update and fix bugs (sometimes a bug can exist for up to 90+ days in this game, because developers refuse to hotfix stuff unless it's Shop related) - Horrendously overpriced items (20 euros for a recolour) - Bad developers (Respawn has lost a lot of respect due to how they're managing the game) - Boring / uninspired events - Takes ages to progress and unlock characters (384h and I still don't have all the characters unlocked just because I'm not playing 24/7) - Too many sweats, not good for casual gamers who just want to chill and play a BR game Here are the things I think are positive about this game - Good gunplay - Good movement As you can see, the bad outweigh the positive in this game's case. Of course, it's up to you whether you give it a try or not, but be careful, the game has some addictive elements that might get you hooked without you even noticing!

The game has huge potential, interesting mechanics and very diverse battles. But there are a lot of problems that haven’t been fixed since the game was released. the main ones are: 1) unstable servers 2) frequent packet loss and non-reg 3) console players with aim assist 4) incorrect selection of players AND probably the worst thing is the sounds. Apex is already 4 years old, I'm willing to tolerate many of the shortcomings in this game, but it's very weird that they just can't get the sound just a little bit right. Very often you simply cannot hear other players, it also happens that even a whole squad running near you may not make a single sound... I hope correcting the sounds will be a priority

Want a great FPS Battle Royal game? Look no further than Apex Legends. Whether you loved and miss Titanfall 2 or you have never experienced this universe you will love Apex Legends. There is a large variety of legends and weapons to play, unique maps, fun different game modes, and decent balance of casual vs competitive play. While it does have in game micro transactions, these are purely cosmetic and have no effect of the game. Also just by playing it is very easy to unlock pleeeeeenty of cosmetics with ease. The battle pass each season also has great cosmetics, is only $9.99 and gives you more than enough in game currency to purchase the next battle pass for free if you mostly finish it (which is not difficult). While this game has had times where players disagreed on the developers focus at a particular time (be it continuing to add too many legends and weapons or the current metas), this game is always fun. Additionally, the developers listen to players and have always been headed in the right direction when adding or balancing new content in the game even if it takes a few modifications. Apex Legends if fun and engaging, whether you stick with it and hone your skills or just pop in occasionally for some fun FPS.

Product received for free Gameplay (9/10): Apex Legends stands out with its intense and fluid gameplay. The game's emphasis on team play, innovative "ping" communication system, and character abilities add layers of strategy beyond traditional battle royale mechanics. The introduction of Apex Legends' distinct "Legends" – each with unique abilities – adds an extra dimension to the gameplay, requiring players to adapt and collaborate for success. The addition of the "Champion" system, where the previous match's best squad becomes the target for other players, injects an extra layer of excitement into each round. Graphics and Art Design (9.5/10): Visually, Apex Legends is a feast for the eyes. The game boasts stunning graphics, vibrant colors, and intricate level design that sets it apart from other battle royale titles. Each character, weapon, and environment is meticulously crafted, contributing to an immersive and visually appealing experience. The dynamic weather and day-night cycle further enhance the game's overall aesthetic, creating a world that feels alive and constantly evolving. Sound Design (8.5/10): Apex Legends' sound design is generally solid, with distinctive audio cues for different actions, such as footsteps, gunshots, and abilities. The game's music adds to the atmosphere, intensifying during crucial moments. However, there are occasional issues with audio balancing, where certain sounds can be too loud or too soft, impacting the overall experience. Respawn Entertainment has been proactive in addressing these concerns with regular updates, showcasing their commitment to refining the game's audio experience. Content and Updates (9/10): One of Apex Legends' strengths is its commitment to keeping the game fresh with regular updates, introducing new legends, weapons, and events. The seasonal battle pass system provides players with a consistent stream of content, ensuring that the game remains engaging and relevant. The evolving narrative through in-game events and lore keeps the community invested in the game's universe. Community Engagement (9.5/10): Respawn Entertainment has demonstrated a commendable dedication to community engagement. Regular developer updates, responsiveness to player feedback, and a transparent communication style have created a positive relationship between the developers and the player base. The active esports scene and regular tournaments further contribute to a thriving community.

Why you shouldn't get into Apex. -20 tick servers. No, Respawn, 20 tick servers aren't "actually a good thing". It's pathetic that this has somehow been allowed for four years. -FOOTSTEP AUDIO BEING NONEXISTENT WHEN YOU NEED IT MOST. -Cost of cosmetics. I'm not even talking about Heirlooms and Mythics, I'm talking about regular skins. It's clear the agenda that EA and Respawn have is to milk money out of the playerbase for as little effort as possible. And, going back to Heirlooms and Mythics - how is selling these cosmetics for $160 or even up to $500 acceptable? Counter-Strike gets away with it because the skins have REAL WORLD VALUE. Heirlooms and Mythics do not. They have no functional value, they are not nearly worth the amount of money they are going for. -The strength of controller as an input. Unbannable controller scripts + CFGs AND 0.4 aim assist. So many people are making the swap because there are almost no downsides at this point. You're saying it's going to take YEARS?????? FOR A FIX? When you could just reduce the strength of aim assist NOW, and put your foot down on these wack loopholes? Actually disgraceful. (Controller players, don't mald, I think you guys should get official tap-strafe binds as well. I think movement is important to the game. But controller should NOT be a BETTER INPUT than MnK. That is like saying you should be able to draw better with a mouse than with a pen and tablet.) -No 120fps on next-gen consoles. When will this get delivered? If it's impossible, at the very least there should be an increase in frame rate to 90. Where is the communication? -Cheaters on East Asia servers and anti-cheat in general. Still incredibly problematic even if it doesn't affect NA as much. -Respawn/EA's refusal to come to an agreement with pro Apex eSports teams in regards to compensation for official organization skins. This has been and will kill off the competitive aspirations of Apex Legends as an eSport. -The story/lore. The recent Conduit cinematic shows that the new writers at Respawn have no idea what Titanfall stood for or how everything connected together. It seems every new character nowadays is some random ♥♥♥♥♥ who gains magical powers, or a shoehorned reference to TF2 without earning it. Conduit gaining shielding abilities from RADIATION??? The Titan that saved her would not have existed until AFTER the WAR?????? There is just so much wrong or mid about the lore and it's constantly sad to see Respawn consistently fumble. At the very least, Conduit isn't annoying as hell to listen to, unlike Catalyst or Valkyrie or Vantage, who are given the cringiest lines to voiceover. -CLEAR BIAS ON BALANCE UPDATES. How was SEER allowed to exist in the state he came out in for over a YEAR, and yet Bangalore, THE MOST BALANCED CHARACTER SINCE THE START OF THE GAME, as SOON as she's popular for a FEW MONTHS, gets NERFED IMMEDIATELY? It was a Digi-threat problem and EVERYONE knew it. Balance team, you are all clowns. The fact that Valkyrie hasn't been re-buffed after the addition of Evac towers, the fact that characters like Ballistic, Ash, Mirage, Lifeline exist without buffs for viability... Don't get into Apex. This is a doggy dog game.

Gameplay: Fast-paced and dynamic battle royale experience. Squads of three players with unique Legends, each having distinct abilities. Encourages strategic team play and coordination. Graphics and Design: Stunning visuals set in the Titanfall universe. Detailed character designs and vibrant landscapes enhance immersion. Innovation: Introduces innovative elements like the Jumpmaster system for coordinated drops. Constantly evolving gameplay with regular updates, introducing new content. Community and Updates: Active and dedicated player community. Regular updates with new Legends, weapons, and in-game events. Developer commitment to keeping the game fresh and engaging. Overall Impression: Apex Legends stands out with its combination of unique characters, teamwork dynamics, and evolving content. A must-play for both seasoned battle royale enthusiasts and newcomers to the genre.

Apex Legends is really fun to play with friends or the few couple of times with randoms. The gun-play is satisfying, the Legends system is fantastic, and the moments where coms are semi-tactical are just the peak of this game. There is a steep learning curve but it can be quickly overmastered if you just play the game with yourself and teammates in mind. People hate this game because they're the ones that solo drop in a team focused game, die, cuss out their teammates, then leave. This game is a team focused game that the devs are clearly proud with. Constant updates, loot pool changes, small mini-events, and a whole bunch of other things really keeps Apex Legends staying relevant; Its a great game. If you play this game, expect to be mad; its a PvP game after all, its not gonna hold your hand. Have fun with it, and most importantly; if you are mad, JUST TAKE A DAM BREAK!! Thx

This city will eat you alive kid. If you let it. It's a big place, full of big dreamers. Optimistic artists, blind German fashion designers, kids fresh out of college trying to convince themselves that their acting degree is worth a f*ck... you name it. It's a cut-throat free-for-all. Every rat in the maze is gonna try to stab you in the back and clamber over your rotting corpse to reach the top of the pile. When I rolled in, I was as hopeless as everyone else. I got off that plane with nothin' but a clean change of clothes and a half empty bottle of bourbon in my carry-on. Nothin' to drive, nowhere to stay, and not a dollar to my name. All I had was Lamar Davis' phone number. God bless that man... He taught me something very important: when you're in a maze full of rats, you find yourself a pack. I signed on with an individual known simply as "The Kewn." He had merchandise to move, and I had a commercial driver's license. It was a match made in a crack den. To be honest, it was pretty degrading, but it put paper in my wallet. That paper put my name on a lease, a beautiful '72 Saber Turbo in the garage, and a God-blessed American firearm in my hand. It also bought a tiny little warehouse down on Elysian Island. Every empire starts somewhere, amigo. Mine started when I was blackout drunk. I sunk the chopper carrying my first ever load of cargo into the harbor, and somehow managed to drag the crate through the door before the law showed up. My assistant found me the next morning passed out in a pool of my own urine. Bit of a bumpy start, but that one crate laid the foundation for what I am today, baby. I clawed my way up to the one percent the old-fashioned way. I wasn't a hot girl who cozied up to some fat, bald Russian f*ck with a fifty foot yacht in Ibiza, full of ditzy, bikini-clad models. Nor was I a Harvard dropout who's daddy paid bail after I crashed my third Pegassi into a strip club, up to my eyebrows on marching powder. Those Shark Card scum who inherit generational wealth all wind up the same. The hot girls get cosmetic surgery in their late forties when their looks start to fade, inevitably facing the fact that they're bland, vacant shells of a personalty with nothing but a pair of big, pouty lips and a sub-average IQ. The Harvard dropouts graduate when papa makes a generous donation to the board, and then they use their complimentary finance degree in an attempt to re-enact before they die speedballing. Point is, unlike them, my hands are good and dirty. I'm out there every day flying the choppers, rippin' eighteen-wheelers down the highway, and having civilized, high-caliber discussions with Merryweather Security. Sure, I could kick back on my Aquarius and pop champagne corks at passing jet-skis every time my account jumps up six figures, but I'd run out of bottles pretty quick. Gets boring after a while. You see, I don't to be bustin' my ass this hard. Anything I could ever want is just a phone call away. At this point, the only reason to keep playin' is for the love of the game. But hey, that's what works for me. You've got your whole life ahead of you kiddo, and you can waste it however you want. Get into professional street racing. Skydive off of Mount Chiliad. Hunt people for sport. F*ck it, play Arena War if you're some sort of psychopath! Point is, you can do whatever. You. Want. Just don't forget that there's a million other little rats like you.

After seeing this scene many times, I have realized that Lamar's roast is actually incredible. By acting as if he's in a hurry and talking quickly, he eliminates the opportunity for Franklin's counterargument, meaning that he can continue delivering his verbal critique. The use of the phrase "yee-yee" is especially clever as it has very loose meanings and is utilized to further demean Franklin while not being necessarily rude, as well as fitting nicely into the rhythm of Lamar's "smack-talk" as the youth say. Since a person's hair is usually one of their most stand-out and noticeable features, by ridiculing his, Lamar makes Franklin's identity feel attacked and being shorter means that he's opened to the perspective of one taller than himself having to look down at it, making him especially self-conscious. Furthermore, by berating Franklin's female partner, Lamar starts to get very personal with him which makes the insults even harsher, while also making Franklin feel inadequate in romantic relationships. As well as this, feigning uncertainty of her secret partner's occupation and referring to intelligent and respectable vocations such as "lawyer" and "brain surgeon" Lamar attacks Franklin's lack of a formal education. Finally, the strange and belittling way that he calls him the funny n word further aims to make Franklin seems foolish and by slightly squatting to make eye contact, Lamar subtly roasts Franklin's stature again, as well as his status, making him feel like an insignificant child. Truly, a genius in the art of "roasting" as the youth say.

Interested in the story or modded multiplayer? Go for it! If you're looking to get into GTA Online, save your sanity. Compared to a decade ago, it's in a horrid state. First off, you're no longer playing GTA when you're in multiplayer... you're playing a sci-fi version of Just Cause 3 on an unholy amount of steroids as you prevent World War 3 essentially. Additionally, everything's gotten far more expensive to encourage micro-transactions if you don't want to deal with the abysmal grind and there's even a subscription service now. The anti-cheat is utterly terrible... can't even join a single session without someone or several people using cheat scripts for the sole purpose of ruining everyone's day. No IP address protection, either. Only time the game gets a "hotfix" is to patch money exploits, anything else hardly ever gets touched. TL;DR: Single-player is good, online is awful.

"GTA V: The Loveable Old Grandpa Still Kickin' While We Wait for GTA 6" Oh boy, where do I even start with this gem? GTA V is like that beloved old uncle who's been crashing on your couch for way too long—still stealing the spotlight, hogging the TV remote, and making you laugh despite overstaying its welcome. Let's talk about the game. It's like the eternal loop of chaos and shenanigans. You've got Michael, Trevor, and Franklin—these dudes are like the dysfunctional family members you secretly wish were part of your squad in real life. Michael, the retired bank robber turned family man; Trevor, the dude you wouldn't want to be left alone with your snacks; and Franklin, the guy you'd trust to parallel park your car blindfolded. The world of Los Santos is still more alive than my houseplants, and trust me, that says a lot. You can be a responsible citizen, driving obeying traffic lights... or you can hijack a blimp, fly over the city, and make a heartfelt speech to the seagulls. Your call. But let's address the elephant in the room, or should I say the lack thereof? Hey, Rockstar, where's GTA 6? Did you misplace it under a pile of cash or something? We're here, twiddling our thumbs, waiting for the next big thing while you're probably brainstorming ways to make us rob casinos on Mars. But back to GTA V—despite its age, it's holding up better than my attempts at adulting. The graphics might not be cutting edge anymore, but the storytelling? Still top-notch. The multiplayer? A haven for both chaos and camaraderie. And let's not forget the mods, because turning every car into a screaming flamingo or replacing the cops with angry chickens? Pure gold. So, here we are, giving this game yet another thumbs-up while simultaneously side-eyeing Rockstar for keeping us in suspense about GTA 6. Come on, guys, spill the beans already! Until then, I'll be in Los Santos, probably doing yoga on top of a moving train or trying to make friends with a gang of wandering llamas.

I am a 45 -year -old father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father raising my son, who is now 14 years old. My son won this game from his uncle, so we installed him on his computer and he started playing. Until the end of the week he had 24 hours in this game. This was horrible for me, because it was hard to find ways to spend time with my son, because he is always with friends or just watching Youtube. So I decided to do a Steam account and get this game to see if I could play beside him. I bought the game, chose my skin and world and started playing, but I was stuck in what you should do. I asked my son for help and he organized a game for me to participate. I loved it, because it was the best time I spent with my son since my wife died. Since then, this game has approached me and my son again and now we spend time together away from home as well. This game reminded me that there is fun in everything, and I brought many happy memories to me and my son.

I like how the other reviews sound like Wikipedia articles. Here's an actual review from an actual person. If you said that GTA V is the best game of all time, I wouldn't argue with you. What Rockstar did for gaming with this absolute masterpiece cannot be understated. We're still playing it religiously, 10 years after it came out. One decade. Let that sink in. The use of three protagonists was a great idea and really branched out this game in ways we've never seen before. Getting three different perspectives on the same story is extremely interesting. Each of the protagonists holds their own; Trevor is easily one of my favorite protagonists ever; I love the Al Pacino vibe that Michael gives off; and Franklin's journey is awesome to see. The gameplay is top-notch. I love the gunplay, and the driving is stellar; it's much better than the boat steering from GTA 4. The story is incredible; there isn't much of an emotional attachment, but it's still extremely compelling and can easily last for multiple playthroughs. I replay this game once a year because I love it so much. The map is one of the best out there, and there's a reason it's used when judging the maps of new games. Online is a completely different story; it's toxic and pay-to win. It's fun with friends, but random lobbies are awful. Overall, GTA V is a 5/5. There's really nothing that can bring down the score.

"Grand Theft Auto V" is the absolute kingpin of open-world gaming, and Rockstar Games has truly crafted a timeless epic that's still rocking it. Los Santos is more than just a city; it's a sprawling playground where every neighborhood has its own story to tell. From the glitz of Vinewood to the streets of Grove, the attention to detail is mind-blowing, making every corner worth exploring. The trio of main characters is a genius move. Michael, Franklin, and Trevor bring unique vibes to the story, and being able to switch between them seamlessly adds a layer of immersion that keeps things interesting. The story itself is a wild ride of heists, twists, and Rockstar's trademark satire on society. The writing is sharp, the voice acting is spot-on, and the cinematic presentation gives the whole narrative a blockbuster feel. And let's not forget GTA Online – it's a whole new world of criminal opportunities. Building your empire, pulling off heists with friends, or just causing chaos, there's always something to do. The regular updates keep the online experience feeling fresh and unpredictable. The gameplay mechanics are top-notch. The driving feels responsive, the combat is satisfying, and the range of activities, from serious heists to absurd yoga sessions, adds that extra layer of GTA charm. The soundtrack is a mixtape of perfection that sets the mood just right. Sure, the graphics show a bit of wear and tear considering the game's age, but the overall design and vibe of Los Santos still make it a visual treat. In a nutshell, "Grand Theft Auto V" is a masterpiece of gaming. The massive world, memorable characters, and the freedom to dive into chaos or follow the story make it a must-play. Despite its years, the game's still got that magic touch, making it a timeless classic that stands tall in the gaming hall of fame.

I really enjoyed Grand Theft Auto V on release, and I still really like the graphics, soundtrack, and the overall gameplay. I find that the driving in particular is very enjoyable, and I don't normally care about driving in games. The story is weak, and focuses heavily on a funding war between two government agencies despite it being obvious that the interactions between the three main characters are far more interesting. However, over time, it has become harder to recommend. Rockstar is clearly making an absolute fortune from the online mode, and thus has focused all post-release development on this mode instead of doing any single-player DLCs. Unfortunately, the online mode is predatory in the same way that many mobile games are, and deliberately drags out the progression with long wait timers, big money grinds, and other artificial barriers designed to encourage players to buy in-game money with real currency to speed the process up. Many features in the online game, such as the ability to insure custom cars and have them delivered to you, are exclusive to online play when they almost feel like basic features which should be present in single-player mode. A lot of content, including literally hundreds of cars and weapons, are exclusive to online play as well. Even worse - as this has gone on, the file size of the install has increased to match it (and you cannot install single player only) - it was around 50GB when I first got it, and now sits at 110GB. This game could be amazing to play offline, but Rockstar are fixated on herding players into their online mode in order to milk them for cash.

The prices you've applied to Turkey seem like a joke. As a country, we didn't switch to the dollar; Steam switched to the dollar to keep prices stable in Turkey and prevent constant fluctuations. What you should have done was convert the price you applied to us into dollars. In other words, the price would have remained the same, and we would have purchased it in dollars. This was what Steam communicated to us. Despite knowing our low purchasing power, you would never make sales at these prices. You can't manipulate Turkish gamers in this way. Good luck. TLDR: Great game, worth it for $15. -Graphics 8.2/10 -Story 8/10 -Freedom 9.6/10 -Capitalism 13/10 As always, it's GTA so of course it will be nearly perfect in the realm of RPG/Action/Adventure games. It's a huge AAA title, so it's going to have some bugs, even 10 years or more after release, but that doesn't detract from the perfection that is the GTA series. There's a reason it's one of the most well-known RPG games on the market. I haven't experienced anything game breaking from playing it on Xbox 360, Xbox One, Series X and now PC. It's well worth it for $15 during the Autumn Steam Sale, but I don't see myself paying $30 or $50 for the game + DLC content/money shark cards. Just buy the "premium" edition for $15 and spend a day or two grinding in online mode if you want the $4m from the shark card, save that cash!

Hello, viewers! This is my review of Rockstar Games' Grand Theft Auto V ! Table of Contents This is the order in which I will go over certain aspects of the game: Story GTA Online Modding Community The story of is so masterfully crafted, I don't know where to start! The story from start to finish is AMAZING, much like story. The only thing that makes story a tiny bit better is the fact that the story never really gets repetitive, which was my only gripe with story. The fact that there's 3 main characters, all with different backstories and fully fleshed out is amazing as well! In this sub-chapter, I'm going to discuss the endings of the games, so if you don't want spoilers, the rest will be blacked out using the spoilers feature. on PC is very dangerous to play at the moment due to hackers and IP grabbers, however the console version (Xbox One, PS4, Xbox Series X|S and PS5) is really fun to play with friends. However public lobbies are not worth going into, because in my experience, getting griefed every 10 seconds by a level 1000 gets annoying after a while. The modding community for PC is amazing. There's many fun mods out there to play, my favorite being which is one of the most popular mods of all time. There's another mod named which is also popular amongst Twitch streamers. There's multiple ways to mod and manipulate the game and I suggest doing that once you've beat the story mode. This game, in my humble and honest opinion, is the SECOND best game, the first being (if that wasn't obvious already). However if I were to rate the game on a scale from 1/10, I'd give it a 8.5/10 (due to the Online mode being unplayable on PC and somewhat unpleasant on console). Anyways, if you enjoyed reading this lengthy review, please leave a like saying the review was helpful! Also I hope this review helped you make your decision on whether or not you wanted to buy this game!

Grand Theft Auto is a series of action-adventure games created by David Jones and Mike Dailly.[2] Later titles were developed under the oversight of brothers Dan and Sam Houser, Leslie Benzies and Aaron Garbut. It is primarily developed by British development house Rockstar North (formerly DMA Design), and published by its American parent company, Rockstar Games. The name of the series is a term for motor vehicle theft in the United States. Gameplay focuses on an open world where the player can complete missions to progress an overall story, as well as engage in various side activities. Most of the gameplay revolves around driving and shooting, with occasional role-playing and stealth elements. The series also has elements of the earlier beat 'em up games from the 16-bit era. The games in the Grand Theft Auto series are set in fictional locales modelled after real-life cities, at various points in time from the early 1960s to the 2010s. The original game's map encompassed three cities—Liberty City (based on New York City), San Andreas (based on San Francisco),[a] and Vice City (based on Miami)—but later titles tend to focus on a single setting and expand upon the original three locales. Each game in the series centres on different respective protagonist who attempts to rise through the criminal underworld due to various motives, often accompanying themes of betrayal. Several film and music veterans have voiced characters in the games, including Ray Liotta, Dennis Hopper, Samuel L. Jackson, William Fichtner, James Woods, Debbie Harry, Axl Rose and Peter Fonda.[3] DMA Design began the series in 1997, with the release of the Grand Theft Auto. As of 2020, the series consists of seven standalone titles and four expansion packs. The third main title, Grand Theft Auto III, released in 2001, is considered a landmark game, and brought the series into a three-dimensional environment for the first time. Subsequent titles have followed and built upon the format established by Grand Theft Auto III, receiving significant acclaim. The games influenced other open-world games, and led to the label Grand Theft Auto clone on similar titles.[4] The series has been critically acclaimed, with all the main 3D entries in the franchise frequently ranked among the greatest and best-selling video games;[5] it has shipped more than 405 million units, making it one of the best-selling video game franchises. In 2006, Grand Theft Auto was featured in a list of British design icons in the Great British Design Quest organised by the BBC and the Design Museum.[6] In 2013, The Telegraph ranked Grand Theft Auto among Britain's most successful exports.[7] The series has also been controversial for its adult nature and violent themes, as well as for cut content.

English: Homemade Landjäger Sausage Ingredients: - 500 g beef - 500 g pork - 20 g curing salt (nitrite curing salt) - 5 g coarse ground pepper - 5 g sweet paprika - 3 g garlic powder - 2 g ginger powder - 2 g dried marjoram - 1 g ground coriander - 1 g grated nutmeg - 1 g ground cardamom - Pork casings for stuffing - Kitchen twine Instructions: 1. Cut the beef and pork into small pieces and pass them through a meat grinder with a coarse plate. 2. Place the ground meat in a large bowl and add all the spices (curing salt, pepper, paprika, garlic powder, ginger powder, marjoram, coriander, nutmeg, and cardamom). Mix well until the spices are evenly distributed. 3. Cover the meat mixture and let it rest in the refrigerator for at least 24 hours to allow the flavors to develop. 4. Thoroughly clean the pork casings and soak them in cold water to soften. 5. Remove the meat mixture from the refrigerator and knead it again to ensure proper blending. 6. Stuff the meat mixture into the prepared pork casings, ensuring there are no air pockets and that the casings are evenly filled. 7. Cut the filled casings into approximately 10 cm long pieces and tie the ends with kitchen twine. 8. Hang the Landjäger sausages in a cool place to dry for about 2-3 weeks. The ideal temperature is around 15-18 degrees Celsius. 9. After the drying period, the Landjäger sausages are ready to be consumed. They can be enjoyed raw or lightly pan-fried. Note: When making sausage, it is important to maintain proper hygiene. Ensure all utensils are thoroughly cleaned, and use fresh meat. It is also recommended to familiarize yourself with basic sausage-making principles and consider employing specific sausage-making techniques. German: Selbstgemachte Landjäger Wurst Zutaten: - 500 g Rindfleisch - 500 g Schweinefleisch - 20 g Nitritpökelsalz - 5 g Pfeffer, grob gemahlen - 5 g Paprika, edelsüß - 3 g Knoblauchpulver - 2 g Ingwerpulver - 2 g Majoran, getrocknet - 1 g Koriander, gemahlen - 1 g Muskatnuss, gerieben - 1 g Kardamom, gemahlen - Schweinedärme zum Abfüllen - Küchengarn Zubereitung: 1. Das Rind- und Schweinefleisch in kleine Stücke schneiden und anschließend durch den Fleischwolf mit grober Scheibe drehen. 2. Das gewolfte Fleisch in eine große Schüssel geben und alle Gewürze (Nitritpökelsalz, Pfeffer, Paprika, Knoblauchpulver, Ingwerpulver, Majoran, Koriander, Muskatnuss und Kardamom) hinzufügen. Gut vermengen, bis die Gewürze gleichmäßig verteilt sind. 3. Die Fleischmasse abgedeckt für mindestens 24 Stunden im Kühlschrank ruhen lassen, damit sich die Aromen entfalten können. 4. Die Schweinedärme gründlich reinigen und in kaltem Wasser einweichen, um sie geschmeidig zu machen. 5. Die Fleischmasse aus dem Kühlschrank nehmen und erneut gut durchkneten. 6. Nun den Fleischteig in die vorbereiteten Schweinedärme füllen. Dabei darauf achten, dass keine Luftblasen entstehen und der Darm gut gefüllt ist. 7. Die gefüllten Därme in etwa 10 cm lange Stücke schneiden und die Enden mit Küchengarn verschließen. 8. Die Landjäger für ca. 2-3 Wochen an einem kühlen Ort zum Trocknen aufhängen. Die ideale Temperatur liegt bei etwa 15-18 Grad Celsius. 9. Nach der Trocknungszeit sind die Landjäger bereit zum Verzehr. Sie können roh gegessen werden oder kurz in einer Pfanne gebraten werden. Hinweis: Bei der Herstellung von Wurst ist es wichtig, auf hygienische Standards zu achten. Sämtliche Utensilien sollten gründlich gereinigt und das Fleisch frisch sein. Es empfiehlt sich außerdem, sich mit den Grundlagen der Wurstherstellung vertraut zu machen und gegebenenfalls auf spezielle Wurstherstellungstechniken zurückzugreifen. Chinese: 自制兰德亚格香肠 材料： - 500克牛肉 - 500克猪肉 - 20克食盐（亚硝酸盐食盐） - 5克粗磨黑胡椒 - 5克甜辣椒粉 - 3克大蒜粉 - 2克姜粉 - 2克干马郁兰 - 1克芫荽粉 - 1克磨碎肉豆蔻 - 1克磨碎草果 - 猪肠衣（用于填充） - 厨房绳 制作方法： 1. 将牛肉和猪肉切成小块，然后通过带有粗孔板的绞肉机绞碎。 2. 将绞碎的肉放入一个大碗中，加入所有的香料（食盐、黑胡椒、甜辣椒粉、大蒜粉、姜粉、马郁兰、芫荽粉、肉豆蔻和草果）。充分搅拌，使香料均匀分布。 3. 盖上碗，放入冰箱中静置至少24小时，使香味融合。 4. 彻底清洁猪肠衣，并将其浸泡在冷水中软化。 5. 从冰箱中取出肉馅，再次揉捏均匀。 6. 将肉馅填入准备好的猪肠衣中，确保没有气泡并且填充均匀。 7. 将填充好的猪肠衣切成约10厘米长的小段，用厨房绳扎紧两端。 8. 将兰德亚格香肠挂在凉爽的地方晾干约2-3周，理想温度为摄氏15-18度。 9. 干燥期结束后，兰德亚格香肠即可食用。可以生食或轻微煎炒。 注意：制作香肠时，保持良好的卫生非常重要。确保所有器具彻底清洁，并使用新鲜的肉类。还建议熟悉基本的制香肠原则，并考虑采用特定的制香肠技巧。

Grass is a type of plant with narrow leaves growing from the base. Their appearance as a common plant was in the mid-Cretaceous period. There are 12,000 species now.[3] A common kind of grass is used to cover the ground in places such as lawns and parks. Grass is usually the color green. That is because they are wind-pollinated rather than insect-pollinated, so they do not have to attract insects. Green is the best colour for photosynthesis. Grasslands such as savannah and prairie where grasses are dominant cover 40.5% of the land area of the Earth, except Greenland and Antarctica.[4] Grasses are monocotyledon herbaceous plants. They include the "grass" of the family Poaceae, which are called grass by ordinary people. This family is also called the Gramineae, and includes some of the sedges (Cyperaceae) and the rushes (Juncaceae).[5] These three families are not very closely related, though all of them belong to clades in the order Poales. They are similar adaptations to a similar life-style. With about 780 genera and about 12,000 species,[3] the Poaceae is the fifth-largest plant family. Only the Asteraceae, Orchidaceae, Fabaceae and Rubiaceae have more species.[6] The true grasses include cereals, bamboo and the grasses of lawns (turf) and grassland. Uses for graminoids include food (as grain, shoots or rhizomes), drink (beer, whisky), pasture for livestock, thatch, paper, fuel, clothing, insulation, construction, sports turf, basket weaving and many others. Many grasses are short, but some grasses can grow tall, such as bamboo. Plants from the grass family can grow in many places and make grasslands, including areas which are very arid or cold. There are several other plants that look similar to grass and are referred to as such, but are not members of the grass family. These plants include rushes, reeds, papyrus and water chestnut. Seagrass is a monocot in the order Alismatales. Grasses are an important food for many animals, such as deer, buffalo, cattle, mice, grasshoppers, caterpillars and many other grazers. Unlike other plants, grasses grow from the bottom, so when animals eat grass they usually do not destroy the part that grows.[7] This is a part of why the plants are successful. Without grass, soil may wash away into rivers (erosion).

1,500 hours in and I still enjoy MWII. I'm close to completing the Weapons Master challenge (for 51 weapons, 100 kills with gold camo, 200 kills with silver camo, 300 kills with polyatomic camo, and 400 kills with orion camo). I mostly played shipment or hardcore (domination, hardpoint, ffa). Some things about MWII that I liked: I really liked the Tier 1 mode. I thought it was an improvement on hardcore more. Unfortunately the community disagreed and they replaced it with regular hardcore from previous CODs. DMZ was a blast to play. I enjoyed the PvE and PvP aspect of it. I just wish they didn't reset the challenges after the beta. Some of the challenges were a real grind to get at required you to have a well coordinate group. I hope they keep DMZ around in future CODs (it's not in MWIII unfortunately). I wish I played DMZ more, but it was so hard to find a good group of people to play with when searching for randoms. However, once that good group was found, the game mode was a blast. For MWIII: I like the it's a little faster paced than MWII. I still mostly play hardcore. I'm absolutely not going to grind for camos like I did in MWII. I just won't have the time this upcoming year to grind, and some of the challenges for the camos seem frustrating. I'm really happy they implemented the Carry Forward feature for the skins and weapons from MWII. I spent an embarrassing amount of money on skins in MWII (probably over $200), so I'm really happy I can use the same skins for another year. I won't be spending much money on skins in MWIII. I'll probably only buy the first battlepass as the battlepass grind has gotten out of hand. It takes too long to go from 0 to 100 and I ain't got the time anymore. I initially didn't like MWIII after the 1,500 hours of MWII, but it's starting to grow on me.

Ah, Call of Duty: Warzone, the game that turns ordinary folks into tactical warriors (or not-so-tactical warriors, in my case) after 13 hours of gameplay. My journey through Verdansk has been nothing short of a rollercoaster ride... with more respawns than I care to admit. Let's start with my highlights: I've mastered the art of parachuting straight into enemy fire, I've found creative ways to confuse my teammates with my impeccable communication skills (or lack thereof), and oh, the number of times I've mistaken a bush for an enemy! Stealth level: Zero. My strategy? Well, it's a well-kept secret. Some might call it bold and daring; others might say it's more akin to a headless chicken running around the battlefield. But hey, who needs a plan when you can blindly charge into combat, right? Speaking of combat, I've discovered that my aim can be best described as "stormtrooper-level accuracy." The number of times I've fired a whole clip and still managed to miss my target is a skill in itself. I've become a pro at giving opponents a fighting chance... by being the least threatening player on the field. Now, teamwork? Let's just say I've redefined the meaning of "friendly fire." Sorry, teammates! My trigger finger gets a little too excited sometimes, and my strategic grenade throws have a habit of finding their way to the most inconvenient places. But all jokes aside, despite my questionable skills and countless mishaps, Warzone has been an absolute blast. The adrenaline rush of those final circle moments, the hilarious banter with friends, and the pure chaos of it all make those 13 hours a whirlwind of entertainment. If you're looking for a game where you can laugh at yourself as much as you compete, Warzone is definitely the place to be.
