Verdict: B Tier, 7/10, 3.5 stars, Worth a Buy? No, if you're solely interested in playing singleplayer or you value historical accuracy. Yes, if you prefer multiplayer because there are still a lot of players playing it, but be aware that you will run into cheaters and that is why I don't recommend it. Additionally, the price is excessive, thereby purchasing during a sale is recommended. The Good: - Missions can be replayed. - War stories can be played at any order. - Skippable cutscenes. - An Axis focused war story. - War stories are in their native languages. - HUD can be customised. - The audio is outstanding and realistic. - The soundtrack is excellent. - Good destruction and levolution. - Graphics and visuals are great - Tutorial sandbox map. - Gunplay feels good. - Good stable performance. - Fun multiplayer. - Improved movement such as leaning and crouch sprinting. - EA app launcher is required. - You can't pause cutscenes - Many unneeded stealth sections. - The campaign's stealth mechanics don't actually function well. - Historical revisionism. - Censorship of historical symbols and the chat filter. - The campaign AI is very buggy and awful. - Campaign can be buggy. - The campaign has very bad writing and gameplay design. - Cosmetic microtransactions. - High Price tag. - 90GB install size. - Anti-Cheat is useless. - Many Cheaters. - Some gamemodes are inactive. - Community servers have less features. - Loading times can sometimes feel a bit too long. - Very CPU intensive. - Multiplayer is prioritised above single-player. - A 100% achievement completion rate requires completion of multiplayer achievements. - Some of the changes to the standard battlefield gameplay could be considered good or bad. - Historical accuracy is god awful. - Arcade shooter with a little bit of realism. - Maps can be big or small. - Accessibility options for colourblind users. - Multiple protagonists. - Multiple campaigns. - 5–7 hour campaign. - There's hardly much blood or gore. - Player customisation. - All weapon and equipment are unlocked. - CO-OP missions. - Doesn't really feel like a WW2 game. - Didn't experience any crashes or freezing. - Stable performance at the highest settings. - Very CPU intensive. - Softlocked twice when using binoculars, unable to change weapons or complete any campaign objectives. During the Norway War Story, I had to restart to a checkpoint twice because the game softlocked and I couldn't continue the story. One of these was brought on the mother getting stuck on a desk. - 4/5 rating. This was a significant step up in difficulty from earlier games when played in hardcore mode. At times, especially during the unplayable stealth sections which conclude in a gun and spray, it can feel unfair. You'll spend a lot of time prone after getting shot, waiting for your health to replenish. I also tried the hard setting, and it felt about the same as previous game's hard setting. Ammo is once again plentiful, and health recovery is still quick. It's horrible, really bad. In war stories, it also includes some offensive historical revisionism. No consideration is given to the distribution of weapons because occasionally you may find late-war weapons in an early-war situation. Censorship of historical emblems and flags undermines immersion and logic. Includes non-historical female soldiers in multiplayer. Same stealth in Battlefield 1, basically. They didn't even make it better. In a battlefield game, stealth portions are completely unnecessary, but level designers adore them. The AI detection is flawed because I frequently saw instances of them finding me, such as on hardcore when they were able to see me through walls and such. Additionally, you can engage in a shootout with AI, and enemies who are merely nearby won't even react. It was a horrendously awful experience that felt unnecessary. contains a lot of stealth sections as well. Only "The Last Tiger" is the story. I advise you to play considering it was good. I'll now give a brief overview of my campaign experience. A rather boring story: 1 man army situations; The dialogue is poor and artificial; The other two SBS members vanish and are not present; Using homemade explosives; A random plane appears and knows where you are; When you are unarmed, a German driving a jeep approaches you and points an mp40 at you; When the screen goes black, the German is in the trunk; Because an evacuation point was never planned for, you must rely on a German radio to request one. German in the trunk remains uninjured despite the vehicle being shot through multiple times; Despite not knowing where you are, a rescue team manages to save you at the ideal time. Revisionist history the mission, such an offensive retelling of the actual operation; Had two softlocks as well; Skiing was enjoyable; 1 women army moments; The majority of the mission is stealth, and you can shoot searchlights but not regular lights; An 18-year-old girl can outmatch males of military age; Instead of shooting you, a German suddenly spawns and charges towards you; Mother teleports over to the bridge; You avoided harm despite being flung from a bridge and falling down a mountain; You plunge down a cliff into a lake in subfreezing weather; You live, and there is no damage to the documents; In a lake, a submarine; Stupid bunker ambush; In a shootout near the submarine, two Germans sneak up on you. Mother flees with a grenade, and the guy shoots her in the stomach rather than killing her. He then doesn't finish her off, and she then blows up the submarine. A missed opportunity of a good story due to historical revisionism and inaccurate portrayals of the Tirailleur; Although there are big battles in the story stealth is still present; In one scene, you and your companions are defeated and killed, and you are knocked out. When you finally awaken, everything is fine. The best story, though, suffers from being too short. Wish the campaign was run this way the entire time. The writing was decent but again suffers from being too short. Unfortunately, this mission contains a lot of censored imagery, notably the German flag. With little to no stealth, the mission is primarily carried out in a Tiger tank. Although it seems implausible that a single tank can easily wipe out a whole army. Even so, it was enjoyable. Also, the level destruction was excellent because to your use of the tank's weapon. The only good war story.

Battlefield V is a visually stunning and action-packed addition to the iconic Battlefield series. DICE has once again managed to deliver an immersive World War II experience that takes gamers on a thrilling journey through some of the most iconic battles in history. The graphics in Battlefield V are nothing short of spectacular. The attention to detail in the game's environments, weapons, and character models is awe-inspiring. Every battlefield feels alive and filled with an impressive level of destruction, adding to the realism of the game. The Frostbite engine truly shines in this iteration. The gameplay in Battlefield V maintains the series' signature large-scale battles and destructible environments. Whether you're assaulting a fortified enemy position or defending it, the game offers a variety of maps and modes that cater to different playstyles. The addition of Grand Operations is a highlight, providing epic multi-day battles with unique objectives. One of the major changes in Battlefield V is the removal of the traditional class system, replaced by the more flexible "Combat Roles." While this change might not sit well with everyone, it adds a layer of adaptability to the gameplay, allowing players to customize their loadout and role more freely. The sound design in Battlefield V is extraordinary. The roar of tanks, the ping of bullets, and the screams of soldiers all contribute to an immersive experience. It's clear that DICE has spared no effort in making the auditory elements as authentic as possible. However, it's worth noting that Battlefield V had its share of issues, particularly at launch, such as balance problems and missing content. But DICE actively listened to the community and provided numerous updates and patches to address these concerns. As a result, the game has evolved and improved significantly since its release. The single-player War Stories are engaging, providing a fresh perspective on World War II through various short campaigns. They may not be as memorable as some other single-player titles, but they offer a nice change of pace from the multiplayer action. In summary, Battlefield V is an outstanding addition to the Battlefield series, offering breathtaking visuals, intense gameplay, and a compelling take on World War II. It's a must-play for fans of the franchise and anyone looking for an immersive and action-packed multiplayer shooter. Despite its rocky start, DICE's ongoing support and improvements have made it a worthy contender in the genre. With the addition of the Pacific Theater and other content updates, Battlefield V has only become more captivating over time. Whether you're a seasoned veteran or a newcomer to the series, this game is well worth your time and attention.

Title: Where History and Intensity Collide - My Review of "Battlefield V" "Battlefield V", the second latest installment in the iconic Battlefield franchise, is a symphony of chaos and camaraderie that thrusts players into the tumultuous battlegrounds of World War II. Developed by DICE and published by Electronic Arts, this game stands as a testament to the series' dedication to delivering heart-pounding action, strategic depth, and an immersive historical experience. From the moment you dive into the action, "Battlefield V" sweeps you off your feet with its stunning visuals and attention to detail. The environments are nothing short of breathtaking, capturing the diverse landscapes of WWII conflict zones in all their gritty glory. Whether you're dodging through the ruins of Rotterdam or sniping from the dense Norwegian forests, each location feels like a painstakingly crafted work of art. But beyond the visual splendor lies a game-play experience that is as exhilarating as it is challenging. "Battlefield V" boasts a refined combat system that strikes a balance between accessibility and realism. The gun-play is crisp and satisfying, demanding both precision and adaptability. Every weapon feels unique, influencing your play-style and encouraging experimentation as you navigate through an arsenal of historically accurate firearms. What truly sets "Battlefield V" apart is its commitment to teamwork. The game rewards cooperation and coordination in ways that few other titles achieve. Whether you're in a squad pushing towards an objective, calling out enemy positions, or providing vital support as a medic or engineer, the sense of interdependence is palpable. The "Squad Reinforcements" system adds another layer to this camaraderie, enabling squads to summon powerful assets like V-1 rockets or supply drops for a strategic edge. Grand Operations, a hallmark of "Battlefield V", encapsulates the game's essence flawlessly. This multi-day mode strings together a series of connected battles, incorporating dynamic weather changes and resource management, all while narrating a gripping historical context. Each encounter feels consequential, making victory taste sweet and defeat genuinely disheartening. This mode stands as a pinnacle of game design, offering an epic narrative that unfolds through player actions. The journey through "Battlefield V's" World War II is enriched by its single-player War Stories. While not exhaustive in number, these vignettes deliver emotional and thought-provoking tales that shed light on lesser-known aspects of the war. They immerse you in diverse perspectives, from the Norwegian resistance to a French colonial soldier's struggle for recognition. These stories remind us that the war was not a singular experience but a tapestry of stories waiting to be told. However, Battlefield V is not without its minor battle scars. Some fans might miss the iconic narratives of previous Battlefield titles, and the initial content launch was lean compared to expectations. But DICE's commitment to regular updates and the introduction of the Tides of War system, providing a steady stream of new content, gradually assuaged these concerns. Overall, "Battlefield V" is a triumph that melds historical authenticity with heart-pounding game-play. It captures the essence of World War II while delivering a modern gaming experience that rewards teamwork, strategy, and individual skill. Its breathtaking visuals, intense combat, and emphasis on camaraderie cement it as a worthy addition to the Battlefield legacy. Whether you're storming the beaches of Normandy, engaging in dogfights over the skies of Rotterdam, or battling in the shadow of a V-1 rocket, "Battlefield V" ensures that history's untold stories resonate through the chaos of war.

New York Cheesecake Ingredients For the crust 85g butter, plus extra for tin 140g digestive biscuits, made into fine crumbs (add 2 extra biscuits if you like a thicker base) 1 tbsp sugar, granulated or golden caster For the cheesecake filling 900g Philadelphia cheese, or other full-fat soft cheese 250g golden caster sugar 3 tbsp plain flour 1 ½ tsp vanilla extract finely grated zest of 1 lemon (about 2 tsp) 1 ½ tsp lemon juice 3 large eggs, plus 1 yolk 284ml carton soured cream For the soured cream topping 142ml carton soured cream 1 tbsp golden caster sugar 2 tsp lemon juice Method STEP 1 Position an oven shelf in the middle of the oven. Heat the oven to 180C/ 160C fan/ gas 4. STEP 2 Line the base of a 23cm springform cake tin by putting a square piece of parchment paper or foil on top of the tin base and then clipping the side on so the paper or foil is trapped and any excess sticks out of the bottom. STEP 3 For the crust, melt 85g butter in a medium pan. Stir in 140g digestive biscuit crumbs and 1 tbsp golden caster or granulated sugar so the mixture is evenly moistened. STEP 4 Press the mixture into the bottom of the pan and bake for 10 minutes. Cool on a wire rack while preparing the filling. STEP 5 For the filling, increase the oven temperature to fan 220C/ 200C fan/ gas 7. In a table top mixer fitted with the paddle attachment, beat 900g full-fat soft cheese at medium-low speed until creamy, about 2 minutes. STEP 6 With the mixer on low, gradually add 250g golden caster sugar, then 3 tbsp plain flour and a pinch of salt, scraping down the sides of the bowl and the paddle twice. STEP 7 Swap the paddle attachment for the whisk. Continue by adding 1½ tsp vanilla extract, 2 tsp lemon zest and 1½ tsp lemon juice. Whisk in 3 large eggs and 1 yolk, one at a time, scraping the bowl and whisk at least twice. STEP 8 Stir a 284ml carton of soured cream until smooth, then measure 200ml (just over ¾ of the carton). Continue on low speed as you add the measured soured cream (reserve the rest). Whisk to blend, but don't over-beat. The batter should be smooth, light and somewhat airy. STEP 9 Brush the sides of the springform tin with melted butter and put on a baking sheet. Pour in the filling - if there are any lumps, sink them using a knife - the top should be as smooth as possible. Bake for 10 minutes. STEP 10 Reduce oven temperature to 110C/ 90C fan/ gas ¼ and bake for 45 minutes more. If you gently shake the tin, the filling should have a slight wobble. STEP 11 Turn off the oven and open the oven door for a cheesecake that's creamy in the centre, or leave it closed if you prefer a drier texture. Let cool in the oven for 2 hours. The cheesecake may get a slight crack on top as it cools. STEP 12 Combine the reserved soured cream with a 142ml carton soured cream, 1 tbsp golden caster sugar and 2 tsp lemon juice for the topping. Spread over the cheesecake right to the edges. Cover loosely with foil and refrigerate for at least 8 hours or overnight. STEP 13 Run a round-bladed knife around the sides of the tin to loosen any stuck edges. Unlock the side, slide the cheesecake off the bottom of the tin onto a plate, then slide the parchment paper out from underneath. RECIPE TIPS MIXING THE INGREDIENTS The way you blend the ingredients is crucial: under-beating can lead to a lumpy mixture, over-beating can whip in too much air. This can result in uneven cooking, bubbles, and cracking. KEEP EVERYTHING AT ROOM TEMPERATURE Keep everything at room temperature. To avoid lumps and ensure even mixing without over-beating, it is essential to have the soft cheese at room temperature before starting. Ideally, let it come to room temperature in its pack for 2 hours. If you're short of time, cut the soft cheese into chunks and leave to soften for 1 hour. It also helps to have a tabletop mixer with a powerful motor. But if you don't have one, a hand-held mixer works fine.

Battlefield 5 opens with a solemn prologue in which you play as a series of doomed soldiers dying in increasingly horrible ways. Its intent, I presume, is to evoke the futility and horror of war. But it feels out of place in a game where you can wear a Union Jack gas mask, jump out of a plane in mid-air, land on your feet, then whack a Nazi over the head with a cricket bat. Developer DICE can’t seem to decide if war is hell, or just cool as hell, which creates some wild tonal dissonance. The notoriously chaotic Battlefield is by no means an accurate approximation of a real, gruelling war, which makes a soldier’s agonised screams of “I wanna go home!” as he bleeds out just seem a bit tasteless. The Swedish studio needs to own the fact that its game is really just a fun, silly, knockabout shooter, because that what it does best. In the thick of a firefight, with planes screaming overhead, tanks trundling by, and sniper scopes glinting in the distance, Battlefield 5 can be exhilarating. And the dense, detailed maps only add to the turmoil, particularly the post-apocalyptic Devastation, which is set among the shattered ruins of a bombed-out Rotterdam. With 64 players fighting together, few multiplayer games are this frenzied. And a welcome return to World War II brings back fond memories of the first wave of Battlefield games. This chaos also results in some exciting, emergent moments that could almost be scripted set pieces, such as the Spitfire I saw flying too low and buzzing a church’s bell tower, carving a hole in the side with its wing and leaving a trail of dust and rubble. But this can also work against it, and I’ve lost count of the visual bugs I’ve encountered: usually involving corpses getting stuck in scenery or flailing around like they’re being reanimated by a necromancer. Ultimately, there are no bad maps in Battlefield 5: just a few mediocre ones This is a series famous for its destruction, but now you can build things too. Whip out your hammer and on certain parts of the map—usually around control points—you’ll see the shimmering outline of sandbags, barbed wire, and other buildable fortifications. Any class can build them and you don’t have to harvest resources or anything like that, but the process is slow and leaves you open to attack while you wait for a meter to slowly tick up. A good example of this is in the Aerodrome map, where the entrance to a large aircraft hangar can be plugged up with cover, Czech hedgehogs, and other obstacles to make the lives of the opposing team more difficult. Some maps even let you dig trenches for your fellow troops to move safely through. It never feels like the outcome of a battle hangs on the construction of these fortifications, but they can really change the flow of a map. Speaking of maps, it’s a mixed bag, but some are among Battlefield’s best. Twisted Steel is the clear highlight: a vast, swampy map set in France and dominated by an enormous bridge, part of which has dramatically collapsed. Below the structure is a marshy forest for skirmishing in, but it’s on the bridge itself where the most exciting firefights inevitably take place around the two capture points placed strategically at either end of it. PERFORMANCE & SETTINGS Graphics options Field of view, motion blur, chromatic aberration, film grain, HDR, future frame rendering, texture quality, texture filtering, lighting quality, anti-aliasing post-processing, effects quality, post-process quality Performance Predictably, Battlefield 5 runs beautifully on a PC with an RTX 2080 Ti I tested it on. But on my GTX 1080 at home I had to knock the graphics preset down to high to keep a mostly stable 60fps at 1440p. I also experienced some judder, particularly on the Narvik map. DXR is another story, and you can check out our Battlefield 5 performance analysis for the details. When the enemy team has control of the bridge, wrestling it back from them is a fun, satisfying challenge. Its elevated position gives snipers a great vantage point on the swamp and buildings below, but luckily the bridge is strewn with rubble and flaming wrecks, providing just enough cover for the opposing team to push through and claw back territory. Arras is another great map: an expanse of French countryside covered in vivid yellow rapeseed fields. The open areas are perfect for vehicle skirmishes, while infantry can battle for control of the farmhouses and villages scattered around the area. Fjell 652, set in the mountains of Norway, is a lot of fun too, particularly the control point situated among a scattering of cabins. Its exposed mountainside location makes for some hectic firefights, with opportunities for distant snipers and aircraft to make your life hell. Less successful is Devastation, the Rotterdam-based map I mentioned earlier. It’s visually impressive and incredibly atmospheric, but the cluttered geometry and lack of clear, identifiable paths to each control point make it feel messy and poorly paced. Hamada, a large desert map, is great for vehicle combat, but the distances between control points and the generally increased time-to-kill in Battlefield 5 mean you spend a lot of time running back to where you died and, if you’re unlucky, being sniped by someone on the way. Narvik and Aerodrome sit somewhere in the middle. The former is based around a Norwegian harbour town, and except for a few memorably tense fights around an elevated train yard on the waterfront, nothing really sticks out about it. The latter is another big, open map ideally suited to vehicles and I only really found it interesting when both armies descended on the colossal hangar at the heart of the map. Ultimately, there are no bad maps in Battlefield 5: just a few mediocre ones. And for an online-focused FPS at launch, that’s pretty decent. Squads are more important than ever in Battlefield 5. Not only can you spawn on an ally if they aren’t engaged in combat, but now non-medic characters can perform a ‘buddy revive’ on a fallen comrade. This is a lot slower than when a medic does it, but still fairly invaluable in the final stages of a match. It also encourages squads to stay close together, as tempting as it might be to run off and test out your new sniper rifle. You can still leave your assigned squad and play as a lone wolf, but the game actively discourages it. Another benefit of working in a team is that, when enough points are accumulated, the leader can call in a so-called Squad Reinforcement. These range from a fire-spewing tank to, best of all, a devastating rocket that can absolutely flatten a control point, killing anyone in the blast radius. The sound of the aircraft that launches it buzzing overhead is always nerve-wracking—unless you’re the one firing it, of course. You can see the explosion from way across the map, and pushing in with your fellow soldiers to take a point after a rocket drops on it is always a thrilling moment. Building on Battlefield 1’s Operations mode, Grand Operations are vast, themed battles that take place over three days, loosely connected with a story that changes depending on the performance of each team. While Battlefield is often a good game to dip in and out of, you’ll need to set a decent chunk of time aside—in some matches, as long as an hour—for these sprawling epics. Each day is heavily objective-based, with teams attacking or defending key structures including giant artillery guns that players can operate. I’m not sure about Final Stand, though. This tie-breaker round is triggered if both teams are evenly matched and there’s no clear winner. Essentially playing out like the tense final minutes of a game of Fortnite or PUBG, respawns are disabled and surviving players are gradually pushed together by a shrinking play space. The last team standing wins the Grand Operation, which kinda negates your team’s performance in the previous rounds. While Call of Duty has abandoned singleplayer, it’s good to see DICE still

Battlefield V was on sale for like 10 bucks so I bought it without hesitation. I've been absent from the battlefield series since 2011 so here's a fresh look at Battlefield V: Campaign: While the campaign offers fresh and otherwise unknown perspectives of WWII, the singleplayer experience lacks depth. It's basically 5 "episodes" with a different protagonist in each one taking place in various fronts of WWII. It feels more like a tutorial rather than an actual story mode and if I'm not mistaken, BF 1 also had the same format. It can be fun for a while but the cinematic cutscenes and the stealth playstyle the campaign promotes most of the time ruins the fun imo and makes it feel like a knock-off Far Cry. FAR different approach in comparison with older story driven BF titles! The multiplayer is actually very fun, which makes me believe that BF5 development was multiplayer-centered. Fun weapons,balanced progression, great character and weapon customization, classic BF mechanics. The only issue someone will definitely encounter are the hackers, 4 out of 5 games have hackers on both teams, using speedhacks, aimbot and ruining the experience don't play on DICE servers, play on community games and just like that *poof* hackers are gone.

I picked this game up when it was on sale on steam for quite a considerable bargain. Graphics - 7/10 Gun Play - 8/10 Atmosphere - 7/10 Optimization - 9.5/10 This game is good if you're looking for a casual sandbox FPS that doesn't require you to sweat to have fun. The immersion is on point, the gun play is polished, the graphics are good, exactly the attributes you would want in an immersive FPS that you can actually enjoy. It doesn't quite have the atmosphere that Battlefield 1 does, as it's more, "bright" themed; lacking a gritty, war based atmosphere that makes battlefield, well, battlefield. Despite this unfortunate aspect, it still beats Battlefield 2042 in immersion and overall experience, which isn't really saying much, but at least its something. Movement feels a little clunky, especially when sliding and jumping, this provides a slower pace than most modern shooters. Due to Battlefields way of forcing clients to use anti-aliasing - which is an issue in numerous titles of the franchise - the graphics are a little more blurry on edges than i would prefer: this makes it hard to spot enemies in the distance. This game is very well optimized, especially if you compare it to Battlefield 2042. If you have an RTX GPU and would like to take advantage of DLSS, Battlefield V has the option, but they force you to turn on ray-tracing to use it, which is ludicrously stupid. Battlefield V has done a pretty decent job at fixing their bugs and glitches for the most part. I would say that the most annoying bug/glitch in Battlefield games are the rag doll physics after your character dies, feeling very unrealistic and sometimes glitching through the map, however Battlefield V is not the only entry in the franchise to fall victim to this specific issue. My biggest con with this game is that the player base is dying, and it is sometimes hard to find a populated server in which to play on, as most of the player base are finally transitioning to battlefield 2042 after updates to the game. Because of this issue, I wouldn't recommend purchasing the game at full price at all, instead, waiting for a considerable sale is the best, "bang for your buck".

Despite having spent hundreds of hours playing this game, i still find it lacking in certain aspects, at least from my perspective. In a 20 vs 20 match, there are typically 3 or 4 players waiting for an airplane or tank. With no means to communicate effectively with teammates, this lack of coordination has diminished the strategic elements of the game. The outcome, whether victory or defeat, seems to rely on just 1 or 2 skilled players. For instance, newcomers might achieve 10 kills but suffer 30 or 40 deaths. On the other hand, experts can achieve 100 or 200 kills without dying even once.

Ingredients: 1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter 2. 1/2 cup white sugar 3. 1/2 cup brown sugar 4. 1/4 cup water 5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon 6. 1 pinch salt 7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced 8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie Directions: 1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C). 2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside. 3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices. 4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal. 5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust. 6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

Battlefield V - A Gritty and Immersive World War II Experience Rating: ★★★★☆ Battlefield V, released in 2018, brings players back to the tumultuous era of World War II, offering a visceral and immersive depiction of the conflict on both the grand scale and the personal level. With its detailed environments, strategic gameplay, and commitment to historical accuracy, the game delivers a captivating war experience that honors its roots while introducing new elements to the franchise. The game's graphical prowess is immediately evident, with stunningly detailed maps that capture the devastation and chaos of the war. From the snow-covered landscapes of Norway to the urban battlegrounds of Rotterdam, each location feels authentically designed and meticulously crafted, immersing players in the gritty atmosphere of the conflict. The single-player War Stories provide a series of poignant and diverse narratives that shed light on lesser-known aspects of World War II. These stories focus on individual soldiers and civilians, showcasing the personal sacrifices and challenges they faced during the war. While the narratives are engaging, some players may find them relatively short and yearn for more in-depth storytelling. Multiplayer remains the heart of Battlefield V, offering large-scale battles and strategic gameplay that the series is known for. The "Attrition" system, where players have limited ammo and health, encourages teamwork and careful resource management. This shift adds depth to the gameplay, fostering a greater reliance on squad cooperation and strategic decision-making. The "Fortifications" mechanic is a noteworthy addition, allowing players to construct defensive structures and fortify positions. This mechanic adds a layer of strategy and creativity to the gameplay, as players can adapt their surroundings to suit their playstyle and team objectives. The class-based system returns with tweaks, offering distinct roles that contribute to the team's success. The addition of the "Grand Operations" mode, spanning multiple days and matches, provides an epic and evolving battle experience that showcases the ebb and flow of a war campaign. Battlefield V's live service model ensures a consistent stream of content updates, introducing new maps, weapons, vehicles, and modes over time. This approach keeps the experience fresh and engaging, encouraging players to return for new challenges and experiences. The game's commitment to historical accuracy is commendable, aiming to depict the weaponry, vehicles, and uniforms of the era authentically. However, some players may still find occasional historical inaccuracies or creative liberties taken for gameplay balance. On the downside, the game faced criticism at launch for its initial lack of content and technical issues. While these concerns have been addressed through post-launch updates, they did impact the game's reputation during its early days. In conclusion, Battlefield V offers an immersive and authentic World War II experience that successfully captures the intensity and scale of the conflict. With its stunning visuals, strategic gameplay, and commitment to historical accuracy, the game stands as a strong entry in the Battlefield series that will appeal to fans of both the franchise and historical shooters. If you're a fan of realistic and tactical multiplayer shooters or have an interest in the historical events of World War II, Battlefield V is worth exploring as it provides a gripping and visceral depiction of the era's chaos and heroism.

So it is finally time to give my 2 cents about this game. I played this game on 2 platforms: Xbox and PC. Battlefield 5 started already good: The feministic move to add females on the front line was unacceptable. But that's not even what bothers me anymore, I unfortunately learned to live with it. No, what really bothers me are the cheaters in this game, using cheat engines, to enhance their chance on survival, and capabilities. Each match you enter, there will be someone in the chat say there is a cheater, and yep, a couple of seconds, after jumping in the field, you indeed get this confirmed. This is awful, and it makes me mad. The majority of my time playing this is on R* Games Launcher where I probably have ~70 hours logged. RDR2 is a stunning single player experience, probably the most organic game world ever created and it's incredibly immersive in this regard. The main story missions generally boil down to: go somewhere, have a shootout, escape the law but for me that's perfectly enjoyable. There's a large amount of content outside of the main story between collectathon elements, strangers & freaks side missions, legendary hunts that make the world a joy to explore. I haven't put very much time into RDR:O - from what Ive seen there does seem to be interesting content there for both PvE and PvP though the PvP seemed a little jank from what little I played of it.
Overall Solid Gameplay Runs decent on low-end PCs Definitely would play again once I get to upgrade my PC.

I recently had the incredible opportunity to dive back into the captivating world of Red Dead Redemption on PC, and let me tell you, it was an experience like no other! Having already played this game on my trusty old PS4, I simply couldn't resist the allure of reliving the Wild West saga on a whole new platform. From the moment I booted up the game on my PC, I was greeted with stunning visuals that breathed new life into the already breathtaking landscapes of the American frontier. The attention to detail is nothing short of remarkable, with every sunrise and sunset painting the vast open world in hues that left me in awe. The transition to PC not only enhanced the visual aspects but also brought a newfound fluidity to the gameplay. Whether I was engaged in intense gunfights, exploring the vast wilderness, or embarking on a heart-wrenching mission, the precision and responsiveness of the controls on PC added an extra layer of immersion. However, I did notice a slight hiccup in the form of frame drops when getting close to water, presumably due to the RTX feature. While this didn't significantly detract from the overall experience, it's worth mentioning for those who are sensitive to such nuances. One of the standout features for me was the ability to revisit Arthur Morgan's gripping narrative with enhanced graphics and performance. The characters felt more lifelike than ever, and the emotional depth of the story hit me just as hard the second time around. The PC version truly allows you to appreciate the nuances of the narrative in a way that's hard to achieve on other platforms. The Red Dead Redemption community on PC is also thriving, with mods and user-generated content adding an extra layer of creativity to an already expansive game. It's fantastic to see how the dedicated fanbase continues to contribute to the rich tapestry of the Wild West. In conclusion, playing Red Dead Redemption on PC has been a nostalgic journey that exceeded all expectations. Rockstar Games has truly outdone themselves with this adaptation, and I highly recommend it to both newcomers and veterans of the series.

Red Dead Redemption 2 (RDR2) stands as a magnum opus in the gaming world, offering an unparalleled experience in the action-adventure genre. From the sprawling, meticulously crafted open world to the depth of its narrative, every aspect of the game reflects Rockstar Games' commitment to excellence. Set against the backdrop of the American Wild West, RDR2 delivers a captivating tale of Arthur Morgan, a member of the Van der Linde gang. As players navigate this vast and immersive world, they encounter rich storytelling, realistic graphics, and a level of detail that sets new standards in gaming. Let's delve into the aspects that make RDR2 an undisputed masterpiece. Here are some more details about the game- Immersive Open World: • Vast, meticulously crafted open world. • Diverse landscapes from snowy mountains to swamps, providing a rich and immersive experience. Compelling Storyline: • Gripping narrative with well-developed characters. • Emotional depth and moral choices add complexity to the story. Realistic Graphics and Attention to Detail: • Stunning graphics and attention to detail set a new standard. • Dynamic weather and day-night cycles enhance realism. Robust Gameplay Mechanics: • Engaging and realistic gunplay and combat mechanics. • Varied activities like hunting, fishing, and horseback riding contribute to a dynamic gaming experience. In-Depth Character Development: • Well-crafted characters with distinct personalities and arcs. • Building relationships with the gang members adds depth to the game. Dynamic AI and Living Ecosystem: • Realistic wildlife behavior and ecosystem. • NPCs with dynamic routines and responsive AI. Immersive Soundtrack and Audio: • Enchanting soundtrack and ambient sounds. • Dialogue and environmental sounds contribute to a captivating experience. Multiplayer Component (Red Dead Online): • Extensive online mode with a variety of activities. • Regular updates and community engagement. Attention to Historical Accuracy: • Faithful representation of the late 1800s. • Historical accuracy in clothing, technology, and culture. Ongoing Support and Updates: • Rockstar's commitment to updates and improvements. • Expansions and additions enhancing the overall gaming experience.

A Masterpiece of Gaming Excellence - Red Dead Redemption 2 Red Dead Redemption 2, developed by Rockstar Games, stands as a testament to the sheer brilliance and artistry that can be achieved in the world of video gaming. This open-world masterpiece is nothing short of a triumph, seamlessly blending a gripping narrative, stunning visuals, and immersive gameplay into an unforgettable experience. First and foremost, the narrative of Red Dead Redemption 2 is a tour de force. Set against the backdrop of the American Wild West, the game follows Arthur Morgan, a complex and morally nuanced protagonist, as he navigates the decline of the outlaw era. The writing is nothing short of exceptional, weaving together a tale of loyalty, betrayal, and redemption that keeps players hooked from start to finish. The character development is unparalleled, with a diverse and memorable cast that brings the world to life. Visually, Red Dead Redemption 2 is a marvel. The attention to detail is staggering, from the sprawling landscapes to the intricate character animations. The game's dynamic weather system and day-night cycle contribute to an ever-changing and living world. Whether riding through the vast plains, exploring dense forests, or engaging in intense gunfights, every moment is a visual feast that showcases the technical prowess of the developers. The gameplay mechanics are equally impressive, offering a perfect blend of action, exploration, and strategic decision-making. From the realistic gunplay to the extensive hunting and crafting system, every aspect of gameplay feels polished and refined. The world is teeming with activities, from poker games in saloons to chance encounters with strangers on the road, ensuring that there's always something to discover in the vast expanse of the game. The attention to historical accuracy is commendable, as Red Dead Redemption 2 authentically captures the spirit of the late 19th century. The meticulous research that went into recreating the time period is evident in the architecture, fashion, and even the dialogue, creating an immersive experience that transports players to a bygone era. The soundtrack, composed by the incredibly talented Woody Jackson, further enhances the emotional resonance of the game. The haunting melodies and atmospheric tunes perfectly complement the narrative, elevating the overall experience and leaving a lasting impact. In conclusion, Red Dead Redemption 2 is not just a game; it's a work of art that transcends the boundaries of the medium. Its rich narrative, breathtaking visuals, and engaging gameplay make it a must-play for any gaming enthusiast. Rockstar Games has set a new standard for open-world gaming, and Red Dead Redemption 2 will undoubtedly be remembered as a timeless classic in the industry.

A Masterpiece of Epic Proportions: Red Dead Redemption 2 Rating: ⭐⭐⭐⭐⭐ Red Dead Redemption 2 isn't just a video game; it's a journey into the heart of the Wild West that leaves an indelible mark on your gaming soul. From the moment you step into the meticulously crafted world of RDR2, you're transported to a time and place where honor, betrayal, and the pursuit of redemption are the driving forces behind an unforgettable narrative. Rockstar Games has outdone themselves with the level of detail poured into every pixel of this open-world masterpiece. The sweeping landscapes, from the dusty plains to the towering mountains, are a testament to the studio's commitment to creating an immersive experience. The dynamic weather system and day-night cycle add a layer of realism that makes each ride through the sprawling wilderness feel like a unique adventure. But it's not just about the breathtaking scenery; it's the characters that breathe life into this virtual frontier. Arthur Morgan, the protagonist, is a complex and morally ambiguous figure whose journey is as heart-wrenching as it is compelling. The supporting cast is equally rich, each with their own stories, quirks, and struggles, creating a tapestry of personalities that make you genuinely care about the fates of those around you. Gameplay mechanics seamlessly blend action, exploration, and storytelling. Whether you're engaged in a thrilling shootout, participating in a high-stakes poker game, or bonding with your trusty steed, every moment feels purposeful. The attention to detail extends to the wildlife, making hunting and fishing not just side activities but integral parts of the survival experience. The soundtrack deserves special mention, as it weaves seamlessly into the narrative, enhancing emotional moments and punctuating the vast, untamed beauty of the world. The music serves as a companion, guiding you through the highs and lows of Arthur's tumultuous journey. Red Dead Redemption 2 isn't just a game; it's an emotional odyssey that stays with you long after the credits roll. It's a testament to the power of storytelling in gaming, an achievement that sets a new standard for open-world adventures. If you're looking for an experience that transcends the boundaries of traditional gaming, saddle up and embark on the journey of a lifetime with Red Dead Redemption 2. You won't be disappointed.
You're a good man Arthur Morgan

This my first and only review on steam. I have literally been playing video games since the Pong/Atari days. The campaign is literally the best game I have ever played. I haven't done much at all with the multiplayer side of it, so this review is almost entirely about single player campaign. it is a crime that this isn't rated overwhelmingly positive. The Game play is amazing, the attention to detail that the developers/Rockstar put into this game blows away any hopes or expectations I had coming into it. You can literally spend hundreds of hours investigating side quests or interesting things you might stumble upon. You can have as much action as you can handle or you can just relax with some hunting, fishing, domino's with your camp mates, or playing poker in town. To an extent...You can make this game what you want it to be. With all that said...The story is unmatched. You will get invested in it and the characters maybe more than other game. It (some in game characters) will make you angrier than you would believe and situations that will make sadder than you thought a game could (if you've played it...you probably know a couple parts I am talking about). I literally yelled at my monitor "How dare you make me feel emotions!" You can play it with high honer or low honor and your game play will change drastically depending how high or low you go, which leads to many players playing it multiple times. So whether your a good guy or your playing as the worst human being ever, there is always a chance for...Redemption. Get it. You wont be sorry. ALSO>>>> Don't join any RDR2 Reddit forums...etc until you have FINISHED your first play through. Don't ruin an amazing story with spoilers.

[PT-BR] Dentre todos os games da Rockstar, senti que Red Dead Redemption 2 é o que mais representa a atmosfera crua e densa no cotidiano, junto com o ritmo lento fazem com que a ambientação seja perfeita. Nota 10/10, considero o melhor da minha vida, porém adianto que pelo estilo de jogo, pode não agradar a todas as pessoas. [EN-US] Of all Rockstar's games, I feel that Red Dead Redemption 2 is the one that best represents the raw, dense atmosphere of everyday life, and the slow pace makes the setting perfect. The character development, the vivid open world (there's nothing like it so far) and the soundtrack complete the experience of this impeccable story. Rating 10/10, I consider it the best game of my life, but I have to say that due to the style of the game, it may not appeal to everyone.

Ribbit! Oh, fellow gamers and amphibian enthusiasts, let me tell you about the mesmerizing experience I had playing Red Dead Redemption 2 on Steam! This game is leaps and bounds beyond your typical gaming experience, and it's all thanks to the charismatic main character, Arthur Morgan. First and foremost, let me croak about Arthur's character development. From the moment you hop into his boots, you can feel the depth and complexity of his personality. His journey is filled with moral dilemmas, tough decisions, and a sense of loyalty that really tugs at your froggy heartstrings. Arthur's story is so well-crafted that you can't help but feel like you're part of the swamp... I mean, gang. The realism in Red Dead Redemption 2 is unparalleled. As a frog with a keen eye for details, I was absolutely ribbited by the stunning landscapes, lifelike wildlife, and the way the mud squishes beneath Arthur's feet. The attention to detail is so hop-tastic that you might find yourself catching flies with your tongue while marveling at the gorgeous sunset in the game. Immersive? Oh, absolutely! The world of Red Dead Redemption 2 is so immersive that you might start feeling like you're a frog on an epic adventure. The dynamic weather, realistic animal behavior, and the bustling life of the towns make you forget you're just sitting on a lily pad playing a video game. It's like I was really there, experiencing the Wild West through the eyes of my virtual amphibious counterpart. And let's not forget the soundtrack – it's jumpin'! The music sets the tone perfectly, whether you're peacefully croaking by the campfire or engaged in a heart-pounding showdown with rival gangs. The atmosphere created by the music is so spot-on that it adds another layer to the already immersive experience. In conclusion, Red Dead Redemption 2 is a riveting adventure that left me croaking for more. Arthur Morgan's character, the breathtaking realism, and the immersive world make this game a true masterpiece. So, fellow gamers, if you haven't hopped on the bandwagon yet, do yourself a favor and experience the wild ride of Red Dead Redemption 2. It's a tadpole-ly awesome time!

Red Dead Redemption 2: A Regressive Trip to the Past Red Dead Redemption 2, the much-hyped sequel to the acclaimed original, has left many players disappointed with its outdated level design, unresponsive controls, and a glaring lack of representation for marginalized communities, specifically BIPOC and LGBTQ+ characters. As the gaming industry progresses towards more inclusive narratives and responsive gameplay, RDR2 seems to stubbornly cling to outdated conventions. Outdated Level Design: One of the most glaring issues with RDR2 is its level design, which feels like a relic from a bygone era. The game world is vast, but it's plagued by tedious and repetitive missions that do little to engage players. The open-world concept, while ambitious, often falls flat due to its lack of dynamic elements. In an industry that has seen groundbreaking advances in level design, RDR2 feels like a missed opportunity to push boundaries and offer a truly immersive experience. Unresponsive Controls: RDR2's control scheme is a frustrating mess that harks back to an era when clunky mechanics were the norm. The sluggish response of the controls makes even the most basic actions feel like a chore. Whether it's navigating the expansive landscapes or engaging in combat, players are left grappling with a control system that fails to keep up with the expectations set by more modern titles. Lack of BIPOC and LGBTQ+ Representation: In an age where representation matters more than ever, RDR2 falls woefully short. The game takes place in a diverse historical setting, yet it seems the developers missed the memo on inclusive storytelling. The absence of meaningful BIPOC and LGBTQ+ characters is not only a disservice to the richness of the game's historical context but also a missed opportunity to create a more authentic and relatable narrative. The gaming industry has evolved, and RDR2's failure to reflect this is a disappointment to those seeking diverse and inclusive experiences. Desperate Need for Representation: The lack of BIPOC and LGBTQ+ representation in RDR2 isn't just a minor oversight—it's a significant flaw that taints the entire gaming experience. The developers missed a chance to shed light on the diverse stories of the American West, opting instead for a tired and one-dimensional portrayal. In an era where players demand games that reflect the real world, RDR2's refusal to acknowledge and celebrate the experiences of marginalized BIPOC and LGBTQ+ communities feels like a step backward. Conclusion: Red Dead Redemption 2, despite its impressive visuals and attention to detail, fails to live up to the standards set by contemporary gaming. Its outdated level design, unresponsive controls, and lack of BIPOC and LGBTQ+ representation make it a disappointing entry in an industry that is increasingly embracing diversity and innovation. As players yearn for more inclusive narratives and responsive gameplay, RDR2 stands as a testament to the risks of clinging to outdated conventions in a rapidly evolving gaming landscape. 2/10

(I'm writing this review way before finishing the game, just to get the 2023 Steam Awards XP. At 74 hours played, I've completed almost 20% of the story missions and about 38% total completion of the single player portion. Didn't touch Online yet _ I'm certain I will play this for over 200 hours. Will update when I'm done.) Despite this being a shooter (1st or 3rd person, up to you), to me it's ultimately a chill game. It's slow like the time it portrays. It's wonderful to just roam through the big map (I'm far from seeing it all), looking at the beautiful scenery. The fauna is awesome: so many animals to study and hunt for the perfect pelts (not as good as the hunting system in the masterpiece "Kingdom Come: Deliverance" , though). There's so much to explore and to look for, so many little events to shake things up a little. This virtual world feels alive. What impresses me the most is the gang's camp. All the time the NPCs interact with you and with each other. There's always something interesting to see: Dutch preaching or listening to his gramophone; Susan ordering people around or complaining about the girls; Marston and Abigail fighting, while Jack is bored; Javier playing his guitar (sometimes you can join in the singing _ some of the songs are delightedly raunchy); reverend Swanson being drunk or crazy; Hosea giving advice to a youngster; Uncle being Uncle etc. When you play domino, there's always some initial banter; feels like you're playing with a friend. I just miss the option of cheating when playing poker. The tone is the most straight I've seen in a Rockstar game. Their ironic sense of humor is still there, but it's way more subtle. It's a far more mature narrative, although their usual "everyone around is even crazier than you" model lives on. I'm not very much into shooters and the shooting is the worst part. It's outdated and not particularly exciting. I'm not a fan of the Dead Eye, it feels gamey in the wrong way. I'm playing with a controller with no aim assist, to make it more challenging and interesting, but still I've been dreading the missions that involve shootouts (they bore me very quickly). The duel system doesn't satisfy me either. In all of the Rockstar games, this feels like it's the least fun to cause havoc. It's like you're supposed to keep your nose cleaner this time _ I'm all right with that, but unfortunately they don't go all the way; imagine what a peaceful run would be like? It's also the most forgiving Rockstar game I've played. was already too easy for my taste, but this just lets you skip mission checkpoints after you die 3 or 4 times. Again, feels like the game was made to be relaxing. So far, the only really challenging parts I've found are the encounters with packs of wolves; the way they circle you and don't let you shoot them is lethal. Since I'm still in chapter 2, there's not much to say about the story yet. I'm confident it will pick up, but so far the story missions are the least fun part. For that reason, I suppose I'll enjoy Online more than I did on "GTA V", but let's see about that. Thanks for reading.

Product received for free I had planned to write an extensive review of Red Dead Redemption 2, but before I do, let me just say that if you enjoy open-world games with excellent graphics and haven't played this game yet, then stop reading and buy it now. I would hate to spoil the joy of discovering what this game has to offer. Red Dead Redemption 2 is a sequel-prequel to the original game, and based on my experience, it surpasses its predecessor in every aspect. Unfortunately, the original game was never released on PC, denying PC gamers the chance to experience it. Despite the latest remaster of Red Dead Redemption not being available on PC, I'm glad that Rockstar decided to release Red Dead Redemption 2 on PC. I played the Steam version of Red Dead Redemption 2 in 2023 on a powerful machine with an i7 12700k processor, GeForce RTX 3080Ti graphics card, and 64GB of RAM, running at 3440x1440 on the highest graphics settings. The game ran smoothly at mostly 60-70FPS with DLSS set to Quality. For those with less powerful machines, I recommend enabling DLSS, as this game is resource-intensive. The game's visuals are stunning, with its open-world environment spanning different settings, from snowy mountains to great plains, redwood forests, swamps, and the desert landscape of the Southern United States and Mexico. The weather system adds to the immersion, such as riding your horse on the great plains during a thunderstorm. In terms of visual design, Red Dead Redemption 2 surpasses even The Witcher 3. However, it's not just the visuals that make this game great. Its level of interactivity, side quest design, variety of gameplay, interesting characters, and Easter Eggs contribute to the overall experience. Rockstar's talent is evident when compared to other open-world games, such as those created by UbiSoft, which lack the same level of creativity and originality. Despite the amount of focus given to creating a stunning open world, one might assume that Rockstar overlooked the importance of the game's storyline. However, this is not the case. The game's story is well-crafted and engaging, which is no easy feat considering the campaign is over 50 hours long. The voice acting is arguably the best I have ever experienced in any video game, even surpassing that of The Witcher 3 and Cyberpunk 2077. While I won't delve into the specific details of the story, I can assure you that it is exceptionally well done, with one of the most memorable final acts I've experienced in any game to date. While the game is undoubtedly impressive overall, there are certain areas where it falls short, especially on the PC. The UX design feels subpar and gives the impression that it was created by someone who has never played games on a computer before. The menu navigation is frustrating and overly complicated. To switch between weapons, you need to hold Tab and press Q and E, which is a poor design choice. It would have been better to use an inventory option similar to that for items that you are carrying instead of the clunky weapon wheel. The game has some mechanics that are quite unusual, especially the weapon system. As a player, you have two slots for long guns - the shoulder slot and the back slot. However, when you are riding a horse, the character puts away the weapons, and they become "horse weapons". When you dismount from the horse, the weapons should teleport back onto you, but sometimes that doesn't happen. This can be frustrating, especially when you need to quickly engage enemies and you realized that you no longer have the weapons you previously equipped. It would be easier if the weapons stayed on your person all the time. It's unclear why this feature was added to the game in the first place. Customizing your outfits is another clunky mess of navigating multiple menus, and then having to store these outfits on the horse. Why? Other games have solved this problem. There was no reason to try and reinvent the wheel here. A lot of effort appears to have gone into making animation for simple actions, and while impressive at first, they can become repetitive and dull after several hours of gameplay. There is also no quick save. Thankfully there is a manual save option, but that doesn't quite work the way one might intuitively think it might. The lack of quick save option is unacceptable for an open-world game. To add insult to injury, you need to create a Rockstar account to play the game, which launches via the Rockstar Game Launcher after launching the game via Steam. This double DRM process needs to be eliminated. There is no good reason for game companies to require paying customers to jump through hoops to play a game. Pure corporate greed. I am definitely nitpicking here with my complaints (except for double DRM which is just the worst), because in spite of these annoyances, I played this game for over 190 hours, and I am still not done yet. There are more places to explore, and more animals to hunt, and bounties to collect. The last Rockstar game I played was GTA IV, which I hated due to the atrocious requirement of Games For Windows Live and other technical issues with the PC port. I had very little hope for Red Dead Redemption 2 on the PC, but despite their best efforts, it turned out to be a fantastic game. Now, I am eagerly waiting for Red Dead Redemption 3, which I hope to play in 2030.

I've just beat the game (82%) for the second time. RDR2 is an incredible game that is a must play if you have 60-70 hours to invest in it. Its slower paced gameplay may not be for everyone, but if you are interested in a deeply immersive and character driven game, I strongly recommend this.

Great game. One of the best games I've played. I just reached half of the single player story, and I already have played 50+ hours. It is such a giant step from GTA V in every sense. The graphics look photorealistic, performance is great, running on average at 70-80fps with an RX6600, Ryzen 5500 (1440p). Haven't really played online that much, but I think the performance there is also great, compared to GTA V. The story is way more mature, lets you see that not everything is black and white, as well as showing the rawness of 1899. They have no issue in showing awful scenarios that you would see in real life. Random events are way more and better than the ones GTA V has. They are very unpredictable. You don't know if you should help someone, because it all could've been a trap. Dificulty is higher than other Rockstar games. Melee combat feels real and dynamic. Enemies can kill you easily, and the AI has improved a lot. Even though the classic Rockstar formula is still there, I think I've enjoyed most missions compared to GTA V. Until now, there is not a mission that I can say I would remove from the game. Most of them feel epic and do have a purpose. And the ones that might seem like "filler" still have some charm to them. Definitely recommending this game.

This game is such an adventure from start to finish, and despite rushing after Chapter 5, it recovers all the hype that was building up on Chapter 4, i've never felt so emotional ending a game as i felt with this one, not even the first entry punched my guts like this, there's just such an exquisite delivery whenever a turning point for Arthur comes. "Take a gamble that love exists, and do a loving act!" One can complain about the slow nature of the gameplay, even more with all these animations playing when you do something, or the Euphoria engine kicking your ass whenever you want to go up a slope, but it compliments the grounded nature of this title compared to others made by Rockstar, such as GTA. The gunplay isn't the most groundbreaking in the industry, if you're playing on a controller, you'll probably end up using the autoaim feature. You'll soon end up roaming around Valentine, enjoying the still wild west, or walk the streets of Saint Denis and have a taste of things to come in the new era of civilization. "We're Thieves In A World That Don't Want Us No More."

Over the years, I’ve played quite a few games that I can confidently say are masterpieces, Witcher 3 Wild Hunt, Legend of Zelda: Breath of the Wild and The Elder Scrolls: Skyrim, Assassins Creed 2, Life Is Strange etc. But rarely have I have never played a game that balances it’s narrative and its open world gameplay so perfectly like RDR2. It has the most alive and interactive open world in all of gaming, one of the best stories ever told, some of the most well written characters you’ll ever find in games and finally, it has Arthur Morgan. The Open World Rockstar managed to make the most alive open world in a game where most of the land is empty. How did they achieve that? By making it interactive in every way imaginable. Every NPC, every animal, every plant can by interacted with in unique and interesting ways. These NPCs are real people with lives that go on in the world when you are not around. They have schedules, jobs they have to go to, families to take care of. You can choose to be friendly, not so friendly, rob or kill these people and every time you choose any of these options, they react to it in a unique way. When you kill an NPC, they don’t just respawn, that particular character is gone forever. When you act friendly or help an NPC, they will remember your kindness and repay you if you come across them again. The artificial intelligence is so advanced that I find it crazy that not many studios have managed to replicate it even now, 5 years later. Rockstar knows how to keep these long stretches of emptiness interesting. That is by adding random events that can happen around you while traveling across this world. These events can range from helping a drunk find his way back home to stopping a huge train robbery. You can choose to ignore these events of course. That brings us to the honour system, you can choose to play as a bad guy or a good guy and it affects how people react to you in the world and in the story. It also affects what ending you get. There is also a witness system. When you commit a crime when there is someone around and they see you, they’ll rush to the law. You can choose to bribe this witness or kill them before they report on you. Hunting, skinning and crafting is also a very important part of this game. All this doesn’t need to be here because this is not a survival game or an RPG but rockstar added it anyway for further immersion. RDR2 has some of the most impressive animations I’ve ever seen. Every action has a unique animation, many see this as a problem because even the smallest tasks can drag on because Arthur has to complete those animations but I did not care. There’s a unique animation for skinning every species of animal, looting bodies, searching chests etc. Arthur’s beard grows gradually as days in game passes and you can trim it anyway you like or just let it grow using a hair tonic. Let’s not forget the highly detailed first-person animations as well. It’s so detailed that riding a horse in first-person can be quite nauseating. All this makes sure that you are fully immersed in this world. RDR2 follows a gang of outlaws on the run after a robbery gone wrong. Now they have to make enough money to get out the country and retire. That’s the basic premise of the game, but as these stories tend to go, things don’t go so smoothly. What makes this narrative work is the characters in it. RDR2 has characters with deep personalities, interesting back stories and a purpose beyond just being plot objects. You connect with every gang member like they are your family. This world is brutal so there is always a sense of danger. The story takes you to a lot of interesting places like plains, deep forests, swamps, small towns, tribal settlements and an industrial city. All these places are extremely detailed and filled with interesting characters to meet. Anyway, let’s just say you will be coming out of this story having experienced a ride of a lifetime. As a side note, you absolutely don’t need to play Red Dead 1 to enjoy this game, this is a prequel and requires no knowledge of the first game. But if you have played it, you will recognise a lot of faces and that’s nice. In my many years of gaming, I have come across some amazing video game protagonists. Niko Bellic, Ezio Auditore, Agent 47, Kratos and Geralt of Rivia are all characters I will remember till the day I die. Now after completing RDR2, I can confidently say that Arthur Morgan is my favourite protagonist of all time. It’s so hard to describe Arthur, he’s not the chosen one, an anti-hero or a good guy. He’s a flawed man who, deep inside has a sense of morality and always acknowledges that what he’s doing is always not the right thing. Arthur is driven by his love for his gang member and sense of loyalty to Dutch Van Der Linde. He deeply cares for the characters around him and you slowly see how he changes for the better or for worse as the story goes on. Your choices affect what character you want Arthur to be but it doesn’t completely change him. If you play as low honour Arthur, he wont just do evil things for fun, he will still have a sense of morality and that can be reflected in his words. Even if you have the choice of being a bad man, playing as high honour Arthur is the most sensible option because you know deep down that’s what he wants. Every interaction Arthur has with characters, NPCs and even his horse is memorable. There is an enitre mission where you go drinking with your gang members and you get to see what kind of a person Arthur really is under that stoic persona he puts on. He’s not a wise guy spitting out wise quotes or a guy who makes jokes every chance he gets, he’s not a good speaker and cannot give motivational speeches. He is just a relatable guy that you wouldn’t mind hanging out and sharing your problems with. I thought Rockstar had peaked with Niko in GTA 4 but I’m glad I was wrong. Arthur Morgan will always have a special place in my heart. But nothing is perfect, so there are some minor nitpicks I have with this game. The missions are very linear compared to the amount of freedom you get in the open world. There were some hilarious bugs that I found like Arthur’s gun getting stuck to hand and beard growing out of nowhere while talking to someone. Most of these are flaws of real-time cut scenes but they didn’t really bother me. The economy of the game is a bit unfair, selling doesn’t give you a lot of money unless it’s a specific shop or fence. The fast travel system is too complicated. But that’s so that you are encouraged to go on long rides. Arthur’s weight system is really not needed. The Rockstar Launcher is as annoying as always and adds another 30 seconds to the boot time. I didn’t touch Red Dead Online, so can’t comment on that. All these don’t really bother me but I listed them here anyway since this is a review. That brings me to the end of this review. As you can see, I absolutely love this game with all my heart and I highly recommend it to everyone who still hasn’t played it. It is absolutely worth every penny.

Red Dead Redemption 2 is nothing short of a masterpiece in the world of gaming. Rockstar Games has not just created a video game; they've crafted an immersive, living and breathing world that transcends the boundaries of the medium. The sheer attention to detail is awe-inspiring, from the breathtaking landscapes that seamlessly transition from snowy mountains to sun-drenched plains, to the meticulously designed towns that pulse with life. This game sets a new standard for the industry, proving that video games can be a form of art that transcends entertainment, leaving an indelible mark on those fortunate enough to experience its rich and captivating world.

Product refunded Graphically, RDR2 is breathtaking, with realistic landscapes and dynamic weather. Gameplay is immersive, offering authentic experiences from gunfights to horseback riding, and is enriched by numerous side missions. The RedM mod further enhances the game, introducing roleplaying servers where players create unique stories, adding incredible depth and longevity to the game. In summary, Red Dead Redemption 2 is a landmark title in gaming, combining a compelling story with a beautiful, interactive world. Its online component and the RedM mod offer ongoing engagement, making it a continually fresh and captivating experience.

BEST $40 i've ever spent. i bought this game on xbox, then on PC a month later just to experience it again but better. cmon, just buy it, you won't regret it. ever since i first played it, Skyrim has been my favourite game of all time and nothing has compared. RDR2 immediately became even with it. i watched my older brother play RDR sooo many times, and when RDR2 released i was so hyped and watched him play it too...but playing it yourself, years later after forgetting most everything, is an entirely different experience. i was in a terrible mental state when i decided to finally buy this game because of Tenacious D. I was isolated for 4 months, and this game is the one and only thing that got me out of that depression. I could immerse myself so well, that for a while it felt like my own happy place where I could finally escape the world. It still is. My entire life, I've always adored cowboys. My lifelong dream has been exactly what this game is, playing it helped me live that a little, even if it ain't real. It changed my view on the world and our society entirely, and it gave me a new appreciation for emotion and nature. I started a photography account for this game, because it got me back into my hobby years after i dropped it. I made 2 new online friends thanks to this game, and I talk to them both nearly every day. The characters inspired me to start drawing again, and I've improved 100x with my art by drawing them. I went from being completely unable to draw men, to ONLY able to draw men. ♥♥♥♥, my Halloween costume this year was Dutch. I barely have the time to play it anymore, and that kills me. Every time I play it now, whenever i FINALLY have some time, I end up crying because I missed it so damn much... This game turns me into one big baby as soon as I see the start menu. Anyway, this game has helped me heal in so many ways I didn't know I needed. Skyrim may still be my #1, but RDR2 is THE best game of all time.

RDR2 is completely immersive and open world. Pros: *Good game mechanics and combat. *Dialogues are well written and immersive, gives the player a good experience. *Combat and customisation of weapons and accessories are brilliant and I personally like them all. *The map is huge with insane side quests and treasure hunts which require to use brains and pose a good challenge. *Finally I like the graphics and the NPC interactions with the main player. It feels real. Cons: *Poor story line with hardly any changes throughout the game. It follows one individual in search of money. That's it and it keep revolving around that same. *Being such a rich open world they could have merged some side quests with the main story and made it more interesting. *The ending for me is kind of anti climatic with no real substance or attachment to the main character. I would recommend this game in case you like open world and side quests. A lot to do apart from the main story as well.

Overall, Elden Ring was a positive experience for me. The variety of spells and equipment it offers and the amount of builds you can do makes it one of those games worth revisiting despite its length, while the non-linear structure of the open world allows you to make your new adventure flow completely different from the previous one. Unfortunately, Elden Ring is not without its issues, and at least for me personally, there's quite many. I won't go into every detail since I admit that a lot of them may come down to a preference, but here's two big problems I believe most people who've also played the game will agree on: - By the second half of your playthrough it will become very noticable how the game almost crumbles under its own size, which results in repeating enemies, dungeons and bosses (not to mention the fact that FromSoftware already reuse some of the content from their previous games). I understand that it was a compromise to keep the world as big as it is, but it also doesn't make interacting with those on repeating encounters any less dull. - The quest system in this game is pure nonsense (and no, this isn't me advocating for the introduction of quest markers). First, in many cases, once you progress a quest to the next stage, the NPC you're looking for will move to a completely different place on the map without giving you even a slight indication where to find them. Secondly, the directions they give you for their tasks are often vague at best too and often you won't even realize you did or found something that can prompt another interaction (e.g. Sorceress Sellen's quest line). Basically, the probability of you finishing some of the quests in Elden Ring comes down to pure luck, unless you're following a guide. It's the opposite extreme I'm not a fan of, but FromSoftware pretty much force you to choose between the two. I could go on and on about the issues I listed above, as well as some of the more subjective ones, but I think this review is long enough as it is. Like I said in the beginning, I had a good time with Elden Ring, and despite its problems, I think the game is well worth your time and the asking price.
