Although I played a few hours, I don't think I would recommend this game to anyone. I also never played any other "souls-like" games. I think this is highly overrated. There are some pros and many cons, but i would only like to point out some of the main issues for me: This game is very grindy. Its not obvious at first sight when a mob will attack, and when you need to time your dodge. For example when a monster lift its arm, it can be a sign of an immediate attack, or it can also mean that the attack will only be a few seconds later, so you use your dodge too early and die. When you see the actual attack animation, its sometimes so fast, that you cant react to it, its already too late, so you need to do the dodge before the actual attack starts. You kinda have to try it out on yourself, and memorize every attack move of that monster (of every monster basically). They can kill you in one or two hits, so you will find yourself dying to the same monster again and again and again, until you finally remember enough moves to dodge enough attacks to kill them. The combat skillset is also very dry: you basically do two moves: dodge, and quick attack. Although there are unique skills in the game, you can only use one at a time, but most of them are just a slightly stronger but slower attack, which will be interrupted anyways when you take damage, and never go off, so you wont really use them. Not much variety, every fight looks the same through all game. You just grind the required attack timing informations, then you dodge the attacks, and do one or two quick attacks when the opportunity comes, and you repeat this until the hp bar of the mobs are depleted. You can interrupt the attacks of weaker enemies, so if you fight just one at a time, you can spam quick attack and win quickly but in a smilarily boring way as you die to stronger mobs. Or you can play as mage, and kill everything easily spamming one or two different spells the whole game. Many basic information of equipment or skills/ game mechanics are not displayed in the game, so for example if you are interested in the full stats of a specific weapon (for example how well it staggers enemies), you need to look for online guides and databases to find it out, because the game just dont tells you. Same is true about the story. You dont really know what is going on around you, there is very limited ingame storytelling, just a lot of similar sounding names, (eg. Melenia, Melina, Miquela, Marika, Margith, Morgott) with one or two line of cryptic sounding reference to one of the many events you never heared before. There are a lot of unjust situations, for example once i was teleported to a different area by a trap, and the game didnt let me get out of that place via teleporting, even dying wouldnt send me back, i respawned there. Unfortunately it was a later game area with strong, and very annoying mobs. Normally if you encounter a too strong area for you, you can just go to a different place, but this time i was forced to play there until i found the exit manually, what only happened after a great deal of frustration.

Coming back to this game you can feel the level of care that went into making it, classic FromSoft formula as always, with many changes that they took their time to make sure make sense in the whole game before implementing them, Open World done right for one of the first times in my entire life. I can write on and on about the perfection of FromSoft games in delivering the most cohesive game experiences you could possibly find out there, from the perfect marriage of the lore to the mechanics and your actual game experience. Unlike some other games where there's a disconnect between the story and the real game-play. The experience also of doing side quests alongside your main objective is quite enjoyable. You're barely affected by missing out on this content whatsoever, but it makes for solid replayability. All fork choices and their consequences on the world have been well-thought out and there has never been any glitch I could find where I could reach some kind of dead-end in a quest that hasn't been accounted for. 100% recommended, obviously not for everyone if you're not into the original FromSoft games, but It is a lot more beginner friendly IMO.

Difficultly and challenge are two very different things, though it can be hard to properly write out the ways they differ. I see challenge as having to do with the craftsmanship of the game, and find it to be fair and fun to overcome the obstacles in a well designed, challenging game. Difficultly can be more frustrating and sometimes unfair. All of that to say that Elden Ring is a fantastically crafted, challenging game, and easily in my top 5 games of all time. A beautiful world, fantastically cinematic bosses, and a challenge that generates an unrivaled feeling of satisfaction help make this game unforgettable. It may not be the game for everyone, and I've had some moments of frustration myself, but it's challenge makes me feel both alive and unstoppable.

Elden Ring is a fairly difficult souls-like game but the replay-ability of the game is immaculate, even if you've beaten it three times there's always more to find, more quests to do, etc. I have 159 hours in it currently with playing on my own and the seamless Co-Op mod and I've had nothing but fun with Elden Ring. It is one of my favorite games and the design is beautiful. For those who enjoy the deep secretive lore of games like Boneworks, you'll enjoy Elden Ring as well. The story is scattered across the entire game and then some. The major story is lied out infront of you as you play through the game and gather great runes but for in depth history, you have to do some hunting. I highly recommend Elden Ring and I guarantee you'll break your keyboard out of rage whilst always coming back to it like an addiction.

Bandai-Namco is the worst. They make Console games, NOT pc games, and more unfortunately, they then port said console games to PC, but do it so badly that it hurts play. This game is designed for a controller, and bandai-namco's attempts to emulate controller commands with a mouse and keyboard follow the standard bandai-namco failure routine. THings that are normally handled with a mouse are forced onto WASD because they can't be bothered to properly program the mouse and menus. For example, scrolling around the map is done with WASD rather than the mouse.. It's utterly Asinine in today's day and age. It's like playing a retro game from 20 years ago... Everything is hidden behind context menus that work great for a controller, but terribly for a keyboard/mouse. With a controller, WASD is handled by a single thumb, leaving the other fingers free to hold down bumpers and modifiers. With a keyboard, wasd is handled by three fingers, with run on shift and jump on space, leaving NOTHING for holding down alt or E or Q, etc, making the fact that most of your needed commands are hidden beneath a press and hold, plus the activation key, nearly impossible to accomplish properly and in time, meaning MANY MANY DEATHS DUE TO BAD INPUT DESIGN.

I would give this a thumbs up. Played Dark Souls 3 after this one and realized that Elden Ring is just a better and advanced version of DS3. Controls are better ( i played it using gamepad and i'm not sure what controls are on keyboard probably not the best ) dodge and blocking with shield is apperently better since in contrast to DS3 you cannot be stabbed in the back while blocking. Camera lock has longer range and is not switched off in most significant moments. Ther is a lot's of exploration in sense when you see something from afar and try to figure out how to get there, then at the end of this path you get a spell or a weapon which feels rewarding. Bosses are interesting ones and fights with them fell like you actually in intense fight and not just mashing buttons. What i would like to highlight laso is that the game is really huge. Still there is stuff that i didnt like. For example one type of a dragon with red lightning for which camera lock was working only on his head and not legs as opposed to other dragons making fight with him artificially difficult. Quests are too cryptic and without searching internet you are not able to pass them properly unfortunately. Also what bothered me is a multiplayer part of the game. You can play coop but you have to constantly reconnect to a friend. But the actual networking connection part is bugged. When you are invaded there might be a lot of lag going on. There is also PVP which looks actually pretty fun when networking connection works. In conclusion i would like to say that you can buy it for single player expirince, but if you buy it for PVP or multiplayer expect lots of networking issues.

I was absolutely captivated by this game's visual style and gameplay, mostly because this game was the first From Software game I ever played. It was curious for me to discover the difference of these two games, and how much progress FS made since then. I spent 147 playing the main story and got all the achievements (almost all, the fact that I have to walk through it again two more times is the only drawbag I found, though it may become a reason for me to wald through it again in the future), and I can't wait to play the coming DLC. I recommend Elden Ring if you would like to discover soulslike games with know doubt. All else who have played any of FS' games already know that this game's terrific

First time souls player - Thought I would give it a go since Elden Ring was so popular, must be a good reason right? What happened was something I did not expect. Today when I tell people I love video games they ask "oh cool, what's your favorite game?" I never had an answer because I have played so many games I could never narrow it down. Then one day, like a light coming on, I realized it. My favorite game is Elden Ring and I didn't even know it. How did I figure it out? I was curious one day and started looking at my play times. 300 hours played on PS4 and currently over 123 hours on PC. Not only do I have 423 hours of game play, I bought it on two systems. Elden Ring IS the best 3rd person action RPG I have ever played. The world is beautiful and weird, the story is vague and action can be challenging at times. I love the loot system, I love the freedom to wear whatever armor you want, the massive freedom to play the game in any style you want, and I will never get tired of the critical back stabs. They are beyond satisfying. Elden Ring is not a difficult game, people who say that just don't understand the game play. It took me about 10 hours to get use to the controls, and 50 hours before I "got it". Things like, its not a hack and slash, and you can't stand still and trade blows with most enemies. Keep moving, standing still is a bad idea, and most enemies have combo attacks and enough poise to finish them without being interrupted. Knowing those 3 things will help tremendously when you start the game. Elden Ring is a very deep game, I'm still learning new things about NPCs and the lore 2 years later. I love it and I can't wait for the DLC, its a day ONE purchase for me.

This game is amazing, with that out of the way lets continue i have never before played a fromsoft game or a souls like from anyone else. this game was my first experience with the developers and i enjoyed every second of it after i got over my fear of the game and ideas that im "just not good" id heard about and all the souls players talk, guess what they arent that bad and the games arent either. i have pumped 291HRS into this game and completed it twice with and without summons as a new to the game style player and i will tell you now the difficulty is entirely up to you as the player for the vast majority of the 60 to 120HRS of your play through to complete any story line you are going for. my first time i dived into the lads between i made my way quickly to the first major boss and got my ass kicked thinking i would be the "HERO OF TIME" or something like that only to find i would need to become way more powerful on my own rather than be brandished by a particular name and one all mighty sword. it took me hours but i found a few cheats on the low level ways to get good, you can farm items,weed the fields for materials, hunt wild life, and practice on low level enemies and sell all gains for runes to level if that's hurting your progress. the biggest point of the first boss is to push players to explore and for all of the game you will gain the most doing so, so please come explore the lands between it is very rewarding

As a standalone game: 5-6/10 As a Souls game: 2/10 Played since the original Demon Souls and there hasn't been an entry in the franchise that has such inconsequential bosses, but which also relies heavily on cheap mechanics to create faux difficulty. Healing is too accessible, which pushes bosses to do more damage to remain a threat, ruining the tense pacing of previous titles. There's also a tendency for the player to chase the boss rather than the other way, allowing for plenty rest breaks in most fights. Being open-world hasn't added anything to the genre but has robbed the world of its tension. When you can just get on your horse and skip most of the game the smaller enemies lose all credibility. The optional areas lack threat, which wouldn't be as much of a problem if the enemies weren't copies, but these issues together creates very stale, tedious, and ultimately forgettable experience in those areas, It absolutely rains bonfires; It's not unusual to have 5 bonfires within 2 minutes or less of each other. Combined with fast travel from anywhere and the previous note on the horse there's no weight to travel either, absolutely no risk to your souls or progression. The game is fine enough to play, but it has lost a lot of what makes a Souls game.

Writing this review is difficult for me. As a Souls Fan, having played all the Demon/Dark Souls games, I was hyped to Start a new adventure on the PC. The game looks beautiful, the mechanics works great and exploring the lands were interesting in the begining. I took some time to beat the Tutorial Boss with the wretch class. This Challenge would prepare me for what was about to come, but already showed me a bit the difference with Elden Ring. I cant really put the thumbs on the issue, but the balancing of the enemies and the bosses felt off. Many of the bosses, which for example didnt Start in Limgrave, would be beaten in the first try, while Semi Bosses like crucible knights would whoop the floor with me. Most of the bosses are big monstrosities, which can still do like 30 backflips and sideslides in a row to pierce you from behind. Camera is still a big problem, especially with the big bosses like giants or Dragons. When you have to attack around the ankles, you fight more with the Camera hoping to See, from where the attack will come. Also a anoying feature were those delayed Attacs, trying to bait you into rolling too early. Souls games always felt Hard but fair. With Elden Ring, I sometimes didnt have that feeling. While for example the Godskin Duo Was beaten first try, it took me a couple hours to fight of the Crucible Knights Duo. Those enemies would run after me full circle and spaming poise Breaking attacks one after the other. After discovering the third Land, the size of the maps started to wear down. I would Start to run through sections with torrent, because discovery and fighting would take too much time. The scale was unnecessary high and felt with the story shortage quite empty. The Options to buy the +7/+8 stone to Upgrade the Weapon up to +24 could have come a bit earlier and not on the last map. It Made the changing and testing of weapons more difficult. In the end I was able to get all 15 remenbraces, but the balancing of some bosses felt very off. Like, I can understand that Malenia would be very strong, but why would it make sense that she heals herself hitting your shield? In the end, I had to search for very specific Weapons and ashes to melt down her Life Bar. The same with the Elden Beast, due his immunities and running fight tactics, my regular weapons wouldnt make enough damage. After hours of trying, I had to research and change to a Black Fire Weapon to beat him. Finishing the game left me with regret, frustration and disappointment. Nothing close to what yould normally feel beating a Souls game.

From the very first encounter this game makes it very clear that it's going to teach you how to play by killing you a lot. When you start it's going to feel ridiculously hard to the point where you may want to quit. But if you stick with it you'll find that because of that learning curve you can play the whole game with virtually any weapon or any build you want it will just take some (possibly a lot) of practice to master the ins and outs. Also because of that learning curve, when you finally do start wreaking bosses all the time the sense of accomplishment becomes that much more satisfying because you put in so much work to get there.

Elden Ring is hailed as one of fromsoftware's best games, combining elements of sekiro and dark souls 3 with an open-world akin to legend of zelda breath of the wild. The daunting boss fights are balanced by the expansive open world, allowing players to level grind and find items. summoning creatures, friends, or random players is convenient, and the massive map, along with the early introduction of a mount named torrent, adds to the game's depth. Im impressed by the fantastic, beautiful, and well-running game, praising its controls, combat, rich content, and a captivating world/story. if you appreciate developers dedicating time and love to their franchises, "Elden Ring" is deemed worth every penny

The Masterpiece FromSoftware's Elden Ring, stands as a crowning achievement in the realm of action RPGs, seamlessly blending challenging gameplay, breathtaking world design, and a captivating narrative into an epic experience that will undoubtedly leave an indelible mark on the gaming landscape. At the heart of Elden Ring's allure is its masterful game design. The combat mechanics are a delicate dance of precision and timing, rewarding players for their skill and strategic prowess. Each swing of the sword, every dodge, and the unleashing of powerful magic spells feels weighty and impactful, creating an immersive combat experience that keeps you on the edge of your seat throughout your journey. The Lands Between The world of Elden Ring is a sprawling, interconnected marvel, teeming with secrets, lore, and a sense of awe-inspiring scale. From the verdant fields of the East Limgrave to the foreboding, otherworldly landscapes of the Weeping Peninsula, the attention to detail is nothing short of breathtaking. The freedom to explore this vast open-world at your own pace is both liberating and intoxicating, as you stumble upon hidden dungeons, encounter formidable foes, and uncover the rich history that permeates every inch of the Lands Between. The collaboration between Hidetaka Miyazaki and George R. R. Martin has birthed a narrative that is as compelling as it is enigmatic. The lore of Elden Ring is presented in a fragmented yet enthralling manner, leaving players hungry to piece together the mysteries of the world. The characters you encounter are memorable, each with their own stories and motivations, adding depth to the overarching narrative that propels you forward in your quest. Elden Ring is a feast for the eyes. The level of detail in the character designs, environmental textures, and the dynamic lighting system all contribute to a visual spectacle that surpasses expectations. The day-night cycle and dynamic weather seamlessly integrate into the gameplay, further immersing you in the living, breathing world of Elden Ring. Accompanying the visual spectacle is a hauntingly beautiful musical score that enhances the emotional resonance of every moment. From the melancholic melodies that underscore the desolation of certain areas to the triumphant orchestration that accompanies epic boss battles, the soundtrack elevates the entire gaming experience to new heights. In conclusion, Elden Ring is not just a game; it's an opus, a magnum opus that sets a new standard for what is possible in the realm of action RPGs. From its challenging gameplay to its breathtaking world design and captivating narrative, Elden Ring is a tour de force that will be remembered and revered for years to come. It's not merely a game you play; it's an experience you immerse yourself in, and one that will linger in your thoughts long after the credits roll.

how to make delicious Butter Chicken. ----------------------------------------------------------- Ingredients for 4 servings, 2 lb boneless, skinless chicken breast (910 g), cubed salt, to taste pepper, to taste 2 teaspoons chili powder, divided ½ teaspoon turmeric 6 tablespoons butter, divided 1 ½ cups yellow onion (225 g), diced 3 teaspoons garam masala 1 teaspoon cumin 1 teaspoon cayenne pepper 1 tablespoon ginger, grated 3 cloves garlic, minced 1 cinnamon, 3 inch (8 cm) stick 14 oz tomato sauce (395 g) 1 cup water (240 mL) 1 cup heavy cream (240 mL) rice, for serving fresh cilantro, chopped for garnish. Preparation In a large bowl, season the chicken breast with salt, pepper, 1 teaspoon of chili powder, and the teaspoon of turmeric. Let sit for 15 minutes to marinate. Melt 2 tablespoons of butter in a large pot over medium heat. Brown the chicken, then remove from the pot. Melt another 2 tablespoons of butter in the pot, then add the onion, garam masala, remaining teaspoon of chili powder, the cumin, ginger, garlic, cayenne, cinnamon, salt and pepper. Cook until fragrant. Add the tomato sauce and bring to a simmer. Add the water and cream and return to a simmer. Return the chicken to the pot, cover, and simmer for another 10-15 minutes. Stir in the last 2 tablespoons of butter and season with more salt and pepper to taste. Serve the chicken over rice and garnish with cilantro. Enjoy!

Elden Ring is a paradoxical masterpiece, a game that revels in its capacity to frustrate and captivate simultaneously. Its challenging landscapes and relentless difficulty might initially annoy, but they become the crucible for an addictive dance with adversity. This isn't just a game; it's a test of skill and resilience, turning setbacks into stepping stones towards mastery. The allure of Elden Ring lies not just in its infuriating charm but also in its rich lore and meticulously crafted world. Beyond the visual spectacle, it offers a journey where frustration transforms into fascination, and annoyance into admiration. To play Elden Ring is to willingly embrace the challenge, forging a unique bond between player and game in the heart of a beautifully maddening adventure.

I had never previosly played a From Software game before Elden Ring. I had very little experience with souls-likes, my only one being CODE VEIN which I had been playing on and off at that point, and never ended up finishing. By all accounts, this is not a game I ever thought I'd be interested in. But there was so much excitement about it on launch. It looked amazing. A friend had taken a week off work just to play Elden Ring. And so on an impulse, I purchased it too. Playing Elden Ring for the first time was one of the best gaming experiences I've ever had. ELDEN RING A Screenshot of ELDEN RING By: kitten SETTING "The gold that enshrouds the heavens. The great tree which begets the pillars of light. O Tarnished, hasten to the foot of the tree." Elden Ring is set in an open world of the Lands Between. It's jaw-droppingly beautiful, diverse, and most importantly - very good at encouraging and rewarding exploration. I will not say anything more - it happened more than once that getting into a new area would leave me in awe, and it is really worth experiencing on your own with minimal spoilers. The gameplay loop in Elden Ring is fairly simple. You explore, you kill monsters, you get stonger by acquiring gear and levels, and use all this strength to beat big bad bosses to become the baddest boss of all - the Elden Lord. Combat feels nice and smooth, and it's pretty easy to get the gist of even if you're new. You have your normal melee weapons, you have bows, you have magic... and each weapon also comes with a special strong ability called Ashes of War. And all of it works, and looks, and feels absolutely amazing. And if that's not enough, the game offers an ability to summon NPC spirits to aid you in battle - specifically in bigger fights and boss fights. This makes Elden Ring very accessible to newer players, who are trying it as their first From Software game. Don't get me wrong though - Best part - due to the open world nature of the game, if you're stuck somewhere, or just don't like the place, you can simply turn around and leave! Return later, or not at all, it's really up to you. You can play with the controller or on keyboard & mouse setup, the latter of which works very well so you don't really a controller if you don't already own one. ...I'll actually go on a side tangent about controls. Unlike DS3, where it is impossible to get the UI to display keyboard controls, which makes playing on KBM an absolute headache of confusion, UI in Elden Ring fully supports KBM (you just... still need to find how to switch it because the controller controls are considered default, sigh), and the game itself is nicely* optimised** for KBM controls. (*not perfectly, just nicely) (**you can do everything you can on the controller, you may just need a bit of time to figure out some Ashes of War with double component - there's some clicking trickery involved) Elden Ring is a game that I really want to recommend to everyone... But I'm sure that, despite what I think about it, it might not be everyone's cup of tea (my boyfriend is still not letting me live that recommendation down...). But, if you enjoy beautiful worlds, poetic and enigmatic storytelling, and engaging exploration, and you aren't afraid to try something scary and new - maybe this is something you should really, really give a go. 10/10 best game ever

Beautiful graphics, immersive world you can traverse without guidance, but you can still get lost in it without feeling overwhelmed and find your path later on. The story, although mostly hidden and only understandable if you look for it on the Internet, is very well set and very interesting. Although it can seem very difficult, there are many ways to make this game easy, or adapt it to any play style or level you enjoy. The artistic part of the game is outstanding. The graphics are perfect and it's optimized very well in my experience. The colors coordinate perfectly and they are very distinct in the different areas of the game, really separating the many biomes in the map. The atmosphere truly expresses the area's stories and backgrounds, surprising you when you all of a sudden change completely the landscape when going up an elevator, or going down in a deep cave. The enemies and character's designs are extremely detailed and you can just take a moment to appreciate the small accents that make up the larger picture. In terms of soundtrack, as always FromSoftware released the perfect accompanying songs that match the fights and areas, they are fully orchestrated pieces from the master Yuka Kitamura and Tsukasa Saitoh amongst others, really making it obvious that videogame music and OSTs can be true classical music. It really adds up to the experience and rounds it up to be a masterpiece. Overall, I think Elden Ring is a before and after in the gaming space, influencing greatly a lot of new titles, and really impacting the player's expectations and experiences with videogames. If you are new to this "difficult" genre and are thrown back by the difficulty, I highly suggest you try it out and, with patience, when you understand the game, you will be able to truly enjoy it.

"Spend souls or lose them" Yes... that same Elden Ring that has some of the vibe in it. There are a lot of all sorts of harmless living creatures (except for the ram that rams you). Good atmosphere, VERY BIG map... and that's good, it's even super. But let’s not talk about that... There are a lot of beautiful landscapes in this game, and you ride your horse “Roach” (P.S. reference to the Witcher 3) through such beautiful places, through forests and even in a city equipped with gold or simply destroyed and all infected. Beautiful locations, many secrets and traps, etc. I will highlight the advantages: -many different bosses and their rewards -open world - a variety of weapons, armor and magic -class selection (there are fewer of them in souls games) -beauty of locations I think everyone who played has their own advantages, and everyone will write what else they like, there are many advantages, it would take a long time to list them... Minuses: -a large number of repeating mini-bosses -some “ordinary opponents” are very strong, almost like mini-bosses (take the crow for example) -loot is not updated in NG+ and beyond (in souls games when you play in NG+ your chests are updated and at least there is something in them and not empty as in this game, this really disappointed me) -it’s not clear where there are hidden rooms (Seriously? Yes. It’s really not clear where they are and you have to go to the wiki) That's all for now, I advise everyone who hasn't played to play it. Yes, she’s not like souls, although I’m a fan of playing souls games, but she also deserves good attention...

Just to be clear I love the game! It is fantastic! This is the first time I ever played Elden Ring (at the time of writing this review). The reason why I’m giving negative is because of a boss called "Malenia, Blade of Miquella". I have died about 60-70 times to this single boss. (I know a lot of people died even more times but for me, this is the threshold) I tried parry, dodge, shield, spears, fast weapons, strong weapons, freeze, blood loss.... basically, anything reasonable. I can still only reach Phase 2 after every 10-12 deaths, just to die from her special attack. (I have spent about 10 hours fighting THIS single boss) At first, I said to myself: "Well, well, well... this is a challenging boss!" Then it became really annoying for a long-long time.... And now this is the point where I become bored by this single boss fight. Don't get me wrong, I still find the rest of the game amazing but when they created Malenia, they really didn't think it through. It feels like they just wanted to do something CRAZY OP boss but they ended up creating a boring one for first time players, which kind of ruins the whole experience. I’m hoping they might change her just a tiny-tiny bit. (No major change is needed, just tiny tweaks to make it more First Timer Friendly IMO)

The Industrial Revolution and its consequences have been a disaster for the human race. They have greatly increased the life-expectancy of those of us who live in “advanced” countries, but they have destabilized society, have made life unfulfilling, have subjected human beings to indignities, have led to widespread psychological suffering (in the Third World to physical suffering as well) and have inflicted severe damage on the natural world. The continued development of technology will worsen the situation. It will certainly subject human beings to greater indignities and inflict greater damage on the natural world, it will probably lead to greater social disruption and psychological suffering, and it may lead to increased physical suffering even in “advanced” countries. The industrial-technological system may survive or it may break down. If it survives, it MAY eventually achieve a low level of physical and psychological suffering, but only after passing through a long and very painful period of adjustment and only at the cost of permanently reducing human beings and many other living organisms to engineered products and mere cogs in the social machine. Furthermore, if the system survives, the consequences will be inevitable: There is no way of reforming or modifying the system so as to prevent it from depriving people of dignity and autonomy. If the system breaks down the consequences will still be very painful. But the bigger the system grows the more disastrous the results of its breakdown will be, so if it is to break down it had best break down sooner rather than later. We therefore advocate a revolution against the industrial system. This revolution may or may not make use of violence; it may be sudden or it may be a relatively gradual process spanning a few decades. We can’t predict any of that. But we do outline in a very general way the measures that those who hate the industrial system should take in order to prepare the way for a revolution against that form of society. This is not to be a POLITICAL revolution. Its object will be to overthrow not governments but the economic and technological basis of the present society. In this article we give attention to only some of the negative developments that have grown out of the industrial-technological system. Other such developments we mention only briefly or ignore altogether. This does not mean that we regard these other developments as unimportant. For practical reasons we have to confine our discussion to areas that have received insufficient public attention or in which we have something new to say. For example, since there are well-developed environmental and wilderness movements, we have written very little about environmental degradation or the destruction of wild nature, even though we consider these to be highly important.

There is a lot of fun to be had here if you are a gamer who is able to get timings, fast paced combat, and quick decision making down to an art form; just like all Soulsborne games. Though I would not recommend this game for someone who has never been introduced to the series before. There are certainly easier Soulsborne titles for that. But for those who are well versed in the formula, this is well worth a play through or 2 or 3. The open world aspect actually does work well with the Souls formula and combat remains as intense and fun as it always is. There is also a vast horde of weapons, sorceries, and armor sets that really do impact how the game is played. Armor feels like it actually matters. There can be a learning curve at first for even veteran players. It kind of feels like I'm a Dark Souls protag facing Bloodborne enemies sometimes. But once you get the old Soulsborne flow going, you're gonna have a lot of fun. The endgame is a bit weird with the boss rush and I do experience a lot of crashes in the Leyndell area. I also do wish there were more unique bosses and more thrilling soundtracks like the other games in the series have. But if you can overlook the small problems with the game, this certainly will be worth your time. Yeah, I feel I have fun playing this.

ELDEN RING, this was the biggest hype train i ever got on, and it was worth it mostly. This game delivers on hidden cryptic deep lore better than any other game i have played and if your going in looking for that you will not be disappointed. Combat being the meat and potatoes of the game is fine, its a refinement of Darksouls 3 combat with the addition of jumping, counter attacks and ashes of war along with the return of power-stancing from DS 2. Spells and Incantations feel like a direct improvement as well from the dark souls games, with more interesting incantations and some interesting spells, they all feel good to use. The exploration is easily this games biggest strong suit, easily outclassing most other games in sheer scale and detail there in. Bosses in Elden Ring range from excellent to horrible, many main bosses are great fights, very difficult fights in many cases, but great fights, the side bosses are generally fine but some of them just feel pretty bad to fight, like the falling star beasts and ulcerated tree spirits. however in my opinion the final boss is a disappointment and the stat scaling from later zones is blown way out of proportion. The music is of course is masterfully made, everything from the somber ambiance of Limbgrave to the grand score of Radahn, its all great. Graphics, as usual the graphical fidelity is not supper high but it doesn't need it, the stellar art direction carries this game into the clouds, it looks fantastic. I rate ELDEN RING a silid 8.5/10 P.S if you are interested in doing co-op look into the Seamless Co-op mod, it is a much better experience and very easy to use.

Elden Ring is much more than just a game, it's a truth adventure that allow us to surpass our own limits, every fight is a trial, every win is a reward ! Exploring this huge world without the usual markers is an unparalleled source of pleasure. Follow us and dive into the EPIC !!

While no longer available to purchase on Steam, Rocket League is still playable here for anyone who purchased it before Epic made it exclusive on their platform. Rocket League is a fantastic game, taking the game of soccer and combining it with RC cars. Utilizing boosts and a 2 "jumps", you learn aerial tricks to outsmart the opposing team, and score goals against them. There's plenty of room to learn and grow, while earning skins thru events and seasonal progression. Rocket League is Free-to-play on Epic, and runs perfectly fine on Linux, using the Heroic Games launcher and Valve's Proton compatibility. *****

Rocket League is like that unexpected fusion dish you order at a restaurant and end up wondering how you lived without it. It's the love child of soccer and car racing, and let me tell you, it's a match made in gaming heaven. Picture this: cars with the finesse of soccer players, zooming around the field, pulling off epic aerial stunts to score goals. It's like a Pixar movie on adrenaline. The developers at Psyonix must have been thinking, "Hey, why not slap some rocket boosters on these bad boys and see what happens?" Well, what happened is pure, unadulterated fun. The balance in Rocket League is like a perfectly executed gymnastics routine. It's not just about who can drive the fastest; it's about strategy, teamwork, and, let's face it, a bit of luck. The game keeps you on your toes (or should I say wheels?) with its dynamic gameplay. One moment you're defending the goal like a pro goalie, and the next, you're soaring through the air for an aerial goal that would make any striker jealous. After 400 hours of playtime, you might expect the novelty to wear off. But no, Rocket League is like that friend who always has a new joke up their sleeve. Every match feels fresh, and you never know what ridiculous play is about to unfold. It's the kind of game that keeps you coming back for more, and before you know it, your car has its own personality, and you've named it something absurd like "Goalinator3000." Rocket League is the perfect recipe for laughter, competition, and the occasional "did that just happen?" moment. It's the only game where you can scream, "I'm flying, Ma!" without anyone batting an eye. So buckle up, rev those engines, and get ready for a gaming experience that's as unpredictable as a squirrel crossing the road during rush hour. Rocket League: where soccer meets vroom vroom, and boredom is left in the dust.

Before this game moved to Epic it was great. Sure the community was always horrendous, but at least the people slamming you for incompetence were, more often than not, actually competent themselves.. But I am not here to talk about the community. I am here to talk about how the game goes if you're not in a 3-man premade team. You enter the game, there is a 90% chance that one of your 2 teammates is just going to sit there idling. There are literally videos on youtube that I found while looking for some answer to this epidemic that teach you how to download a bot that will make it so the idle-kick mechanic doesn't detect you idling. All because of ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ loot crates and XP farming... So.. Now you have a bunch of 10-14 year olds who used to have to ask permission to get a game who just get to join in with no consequence or restriction. On top of that, you have every trade-scammer able to make 200 accounts and just infinitely ruin games with no repercussions.. This game is ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. Every match is like swimming through raw sewage looking for a platinum turd to make it worthwhile and then, once you think you found it, it's just a regular turd sprayed with chrome. If you don't have enough people to fill a team of your preferred size (2 or 3), who want to play and practice with you constantly.... Don't ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ bother.

I've played this game since 2015. The first time I played it quickly turned into an all night and all next morning game session. I had work at 8am, called off to sleep and play more car soccer instead. The game has experienced many changes and mechanical discoveries since those days. I never was interested in ranked, so I played mostly casual lobbies and free play. However, I am interested in seeing where I stand these days. The best times are when you are just feeling like you are part of the car. You are executing everything you are capable of seeing at will. You can make no mistake, the vibe. The worst times are when you encounter a toxic community member or you go on a losing streak of hard fought OT games. Lots of opportunities to experience the highest of highs or the lowest of lows. My advice is to control your emotions, have fun, and set the good example. You can not control what someone else does, but you can control how you respond \ react. The game is FREE on Epic now. Not even sure you can get it on Steam anymore.

This is as close as it gets to a perfect video game. An extremely low skill floor and an impossibly high skill ceiling. With the simplest objective of 'get the ball in the goal', and a million different ways to make that happen, I have little doubt that I will be playing this for many more years to come. Super fast to boot up and get into a match, and matches last 5-10 minutes, then you are on to the next one. Easy to pick up and play and come back to over and over. So if it is 2023 or later and you are on the fence about playing a free to play game that has been out for years and are reading this review, just install it. 10/10 game

8/10 Content - Would give 10 but Epic ruined it. Thanks Epic Games! Do not under any circumstances play this game with voice or text chat turned on. Unless you like torture. Text chat is filled with 4ssholes with big egos who think they are amazing but play like they are drunk and blame you for everything, unless they decide to own-goal you until you quit, then they mysteriously become SSL. NOPE, people talk sh!t like it's their day job and blame you for their mistakes. It only gets worse if you respond too. Really wish this game was not free to play, it would at least take some of the trolls and 4ssholes out of the game.

Ah, Rocket League. What started as a beautiful romance between me and this vehicular soccer game quickly turned sour, leaving me feeling bewildered and resentful. With a heavy heart, I bid farewell to a relationship that once brought joy but eventually descended into frustration and disappointment. Initial Infatuation: In the beginning, Rocket League had me smitten. The excitement of fast-paced matches and gravity-defying stunts filled me with a sense of wonder. It was love at first boost as I glued my eyes to the screen, adoring the beautiful fusion of cars and football. The potential seemed limitless, and I was prepared to dive headfirst into this exhilarating relationship. The Ups and Downs: Like any tumultuous relationship, Rocket League had its fair share of ups and downs. At times, I found myself flying high with epic goals and remarkable saves, basking in the glory of victory. These moments were nothing short of electrifying and undeniably addictive. However, these highs were frequently met with crushing defeats, leaving me frustrated and questioning my own abilities. [6:48 PM] Communication Breakdown: Somewhere along the way, communication between Rocket League and me deteriorated. Whether it was the unpredictable physics, unreliable servers, or the relentless opponents who seemed to defy logic, our once harmonious connection transformed into a jumbled mess. It became increasingly difficult to predict the game's whims, and this lack of consistency fueled my mounting resentment. The Toxic Players: Ah, the toxicity that seeped into our relationship! Rocket League unfortunately attracted a slew of players who thrived on taunting and belittling their opponents. The insults hurled at me were a constant [6:48 PM] reminder that the community had become a breeding ground for negativity. It was disheartening to witness the demise of the once-uplifting atmosphere that captured my heart. The Breaking Point: Finally, after enduring countless heart-wrenching defeats and enduring toxicity, I reached my breaking point. The initial love that captured my soul had eroded into an overwhelming frustration that no amount of satisfying goals could alleviate. Our breakup became inevitable, as the relief of walking away outweighed the lingering remnants of affection. Conclusion: Rocket League, our journey together has indeed been a rocky one. What began as a passionate affair eventually soured, plagued by inconsistent gameplay, toxic attitudes, and the bittersweet taste of defeat. While there were moments of undeniable pleasure, the overall experience left me longing for something more stable and fulfilling. It's time for me to bid adieu to this turbulent relationship and seek solace elsewhere in the gaming world.

Abusive teammates will flame you in chat and sabotage the game for the smallest mistakes. Memories of your dad yelling at you in pee wee soccer come rushing back. Matchmaking is also plagued with smurfs who'll stunt on you like Team Iceland in D2: The Mighty Ducks. Psyonix's response to smurfing is unfortunately laissez-faire. That being said, it's a totally unique competitive experience in gameplay if not community. The closest you can get to simulating sports with a controller in your hands. Most importantly, it's fun at every point of the learning curve. And with a bit of persistence, you'll be pulling off moves you never thought capable of your old hands. You might eventually reflect on how much better your life could've been if you applied the same level of focus to something constructive... nah. This is Rocket League!

Uninstalled, game officially ruined and is only for EPIC's consistent cash grab (which they are getting sued for or were already sued by the way) - The RED Disney Cars car sealed the deal. Likely the best game defining what e-sports should look like continues to do stupid little cash grabs for what is nothing more than a 3d model and a texture wrapped around it. It has no tangible value (not even for trade)... but it devalued the ♥♥♥♥ out of a game that has teams that are deciphered by color. When was the last time you saw two teams in any sport where half of each team wore the jersey of the opposing team? Are you ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ kidding me? So now instead of playing rocket league, you're playing "name plate league" because that's the only thing that visually identifies the player of the opposing team by color. But hey, i suppose every team player in football (no matter which kind of football you choose) should all wear different color jerseys... You let me know how the game pans out when you instead have to remember the numbers on the jersey instead of the team that represents you by the way they look. This would be the equivalent of playing counter-strike, being on the counter-terrorist team, but using a terrorist skin.... its stupid AF for any competitive activity where teams should appear similar. I know a bunch of you nerds are into air soft. Are you allowed to be on the red team and wear a blue stripe on your arm vs a red one? NOPE, because ITS NOT FAIR lol... ♥♥♥ basic. bye now, please join me in leaving this game behind as well as all other EPIC owned titles..

Rocket League is the ultimate gaming experience for competitive gameplay. There is no way to play this game without trying to learn a new way to manipulate these vehicles both through the air and around the field. Even after playing this game for 233 hours, it is still engaging and keeps players on their toes. You will not find a game like this and it stands the test of time as the player count continues to keep it one of the most played games on steam!

My opinions about Rocket League: The single most competitive game I've ever played that also requires a skill set that can be learned from both experience and through training. This provides the challenge I prefer in games. As far as training goes, there is an abundance of pro and others that are willing to teach what they have learned -- skills and mechanics -- to improve your game. Finally; IF you get "Good Enough" to go "Pro" - SSL+ it may be possible to earn some "extra cash" while playing Rocket League. Yeppur!!

At the beginning of the path down the trash can, Rocket League was removed from Steam, but remained playable for everyone who bought it at the time. Ok, the Steam community thought, what the hell. Epic had once again put money on the table and lured or bought the developers. Next, trading and crafting items were made more difficult and blueprints were introduced that everyone hates. Ok, thinks the community, it only goes downhill from here. Last but not least, in-game item trading between players has been completely removed from the game. Wow... I'm almost ashamed that I thought back then that Psyonix had turned a cool concept into a top game with Rocket League and had done a good job using fair methods and skin systems. The Steam community that made Rocket League the money-making machine it is today is now just tolerated and eventually thrown in the trash. Another good example of how capitalism turns the best man into the greediest moneybag who doesn't give a ♥♥♥♥ about anything.

Over 1000 hours in this game. Loved it since launch and always come back to it. Removing player trading is BY FAR the stupidest decision any company has ever made for any singular game that I have ever seen. If you don't understand why this matters, I want you to imagine if DOTA2 or CSGO removed trading. Yes, that is how stupid this decision is. Pure unadulterated greed and tone-deafness of epic games. People have made full-on businesses with player trading involved. Epic is removing it, and then charging 3x the price for items that could have been traded from player to player. Want to buy a Fennec body? that'll be 1000 credits instead of the average 300 credits you can get it for from other players. Want to get a cool goal explosion? That'll be 1800 credits instead of ~500 credits or so. Want to get some neat wheels that aren't super rare? That'll be 300 credits instead of 50 credits. Epic doesn't care about you. They want more money.

I don't care about trading unlike the majority of the fanbase, which I respect. But the biggest problem for me in recent months is matchmaking. I've always loved this game for a fair TRUE skill-based matchmaking, when every game was a challenge and a nail-biter with close scores. But recently everything changed and I have no idea why, maybe because there are not so many players left. One game you play against people who are obviously a lot less skilled than you and it ends up in a forfeit, the very next game we are playing against absolute monsters and get crashed the same way. I have an unhealthy love for this game. The game used to be a great game to get on and vibe and play casually or competitively. Trading was a huge thing in the game that gave the whole player base something else to enjoy and have fun with and they took it away so they can be money hogging pigs once again. Epic is known to value money over everything. First it was crates taken away, now its trading. The game is bound to fail sooner than later. It used to be a "flex" to have certain toppers, wheels, boosts, goal explosions, decals, and Epic decided to take that away so they can implement a new kind of shop where all of these items are just going to constantly cycle in and out. Now yes, there has been a shop for a long time where they would cycle some hot topic items that would "force" players to buy them due to FOMO (fear of missing out). I used to be a huge trader and collector myself and that fact that they are taking it all away is going to be a huge detriment to the game. My time on the game was fun, but they seem to just keep ruining it more and more.

Rocket League bukan sebuah "permainan olahraga" dan lebih merupakan olahraga yang sebenarnya. Di FIFA atau Madden, Anda memiliki tombol "oper", tetapi untuk melakukan operan di Rocket League, Anda harus mengemudikan mobil Anda ke arah bola dengan kecepatan dan sudut yang tepat untuk mengirimkannya ke arah rekan satu tim Anda. Anda harus membuat operan sendiri, dan bisa berupa apa saja, mulai dari pantulan keras dari dinding belakang hingga lob lembut melewati pemain bertahan. Mengumpan, menembak, menggiring bola, melakukan tekel, melakukan gerakan tipuan, semuanya ada di dalam permainan, tetapi Anda harus mewujudkannya sendiri, bukan hanya menekan tombol yang tepat. Pada awalnya, mengemudikan mobil ke bola saja sudah merupakan tantangan, tetapi seiring dengan meningkatnya keahlian Anda, kebebasan untuk menciptakan permainan apa pun yang dapat Anda bayangkan dan jalankan tidak seperti apa pun yang Anda temukan dalam "permainan olahraga". Bersama dengan keterampilan mekanis untuk melakukan apa yang Anda inginkan dengan bola, Anda harus mengembangkan kesadaran posisi dan mempelajari rotasi yang tepat dan rasa permainan.
